his Uncle to be hid, and we shall prove him to be the Author of them; and yet that this man should have the confidence to ſay he is a good Subject and a good Proteſtant, when by all ways imaginable he goes about to ruin the Government, and defame the King! And Gentlemen when we have given you this account by Witneſſes, for I would have you believe me in nothing, but according as I prove it, you will not wonder then that he should ſay his Life is in danger, (for ſo it is indeed.) And if any man ever was Guilty of High Treaſon, ſure he is, and being Guilty of the greateſt Treaſon, he deſerves the ſevereſt Punishment.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen of the Jury, take Mr. Attorney at his word, and remember Sir, you deſire not to be believed your ſelf, but what you prove.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Holloway.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordship, and Gentlemen, purſuant to what Mr. Attorney hath opened, we will call our Witneſſes, and we will begin with Mr. Dugdale, who was a Witneſs againſt my Lord Stafford, at his Tryal in Parliament, whoſe credit Mr. Colledge did atteſt at that Tryal, aſſerting him to be an honeſt good man, and I believe his evidence will go in a great meaſure thro •• l that Mr. Attorn. hath opened, & when we have done with him, we hope to ſecond him with other Witneſſes of as good credit, and that will ſay as much to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale, look upon the Priſoner, and tell the Court whether you know him.

div.stage: Mr. Dugdale. Yes, I do know him Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Will you give us an account of your knowledge of him?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly deſire they may be examined apart, and not in the hearing one of another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That with ſubmiſſion ought not to be in the Kings Caſe, though we think there are none of them, that will ſpeak any more then the Truth.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Here are ſeveral of them my Lord, they are all of a gang.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jefferies.
sp.p: Not of your gang, Mr. Colledge.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I pray they may go out my Lord. (Which was done accordingly.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: If your Lordships pleaſe, whether or no I may deliver in theſe papers?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. G.
sp.p: By & by, time enough when we ask for them, ſpeak your own knowledg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lord, I have been I think acquainted with Mr. Colledge 2 years or thereabouts. I have been ſeveral times in Mr. Colledges company, and truly ſometimes he hath been mightily bent againſt Popery; he hath at ſometimes uttered himſelf, becauſe the King did not proſecute the Papiſts according as he thought ſufficiently, that the King was a Papiſt himſelf, that he was as deep in the Plot as any Papiſt of them all, that he had an Hand in Sir Edmondbury Godfry's Death. This Mr. Colledge I appeal to your ſelf, whether you have not ſaid it: And in this Town of Oxford you have ſeveral times told me that nothing was to be expected from him, he would no nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt Levinz.
sp.p: Who did tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Mr. Colledge did tell me that there was nothing to be expected from the King, but the introducing of Popery and Arbitrary Government, this I belive Mr. Colledge will acknowledge to be true.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Where was this ſpoken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: This was ſpoken at a Coffee-Houſe, called Combe's Coffee-Houſe in this Town, and at the Angel-Inn in this Town at a Barbers Shop; that day the King went out of Town, we were in the ſame Shop.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Who was there beſides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Do not interrupt our Witneſſes, let us have done with him, and you shall have time to ask him queſtions after.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: For your Inſtruction, I will tell you, your time is not yet come, if you chop in, and interrupt the Witneſſes, you will diſturb any man living; but your way is this, when he hath delivered his teſtimony, ask him any queſtions then, and he shall be bound to anſwer you, and in the mean time you shall have pen, ink and paper, to help your memory.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: That day the King went out of Town, preſently after he went, you and I went into the Angel-Inn: and we went into the Barbers-Shop that is juſt within the Inn, and being charging your Piſtols there, you ſaid Rowley was gone, the Rogue was afraid of himſelf, he was shirked away, and here I appeal to your own conſcience, whether you did not ſpeak it?

div.stage: Coll. I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Don't appeal to him, 'tis nothing for that.

sp.speaker: Mt. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who did he mean by Rowley?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Was that his common application for the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: It was his common word concerning the King. And at other times ſpeaking that the King did not do thoſe things that were fair, he hath given mighty great words againſt him: He hath told me that there was no truſt to be put in him; for it was the People we muſt truſt to, and we muſt look to arm our ſelves, and that he would arm himſelf, and be here at Oxford, and he told me here in the Town accordingly, when I came out of the Countrey, and he ſaid that he had ſeveral ſtout men that would ſtand by him in it. Their intention was, as he ſaid, for the rooting out of Popery, by which name he always termed the Church that is now eſtablished by Law, as to be of the ſame nature the Papiſts were. This I believe Mr. Colledge will acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Well, go on Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: And at a time when he had Dr. Tongue at his Houſe, he told me, that as for Dr. Tongue, he had much ado with him, and he had been at a great charge to keep him in order, that he was forced to neglect his own buſineſs to look after him; for if he had not done ſo, the Rogue, as he ſaid, had a mind to fling all upon the Proteſtants, that is, the Diſſenters; for he does not count the Church of England to be ſo; that he had much ado to keep him in order; for he had ſaid he had drawn Papers to that purpoſe, but thoſe papers are ſecured; for where they are, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who were they that were to be with him in that deſign of his?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He told me Captain Chinton, Captain Browne, and one Dr. Lewes, and he brought them into Town here, when he came with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: To what purpoſe did he bring them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Expecting there would be a riſing.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Did he tell you that here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, the Friday, I think it was, after the Parliament firſt ſat.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: How did he expreſs himſelf? what they had to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: They were to be here, in caſe there were any riſing, which he expected.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: What uſe did he ſay he would make of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: For the defence of the Proteſtant Religion, againſt the King and all his Adherents.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: What did he ſay he would do to the King? I would not lead you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He did not ſay what particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: What did he ſay if the King did not yield to the Parliament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: If the King did not yield to the Parliament, he should be forced to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Where did you hear him ſay that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: At Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Did you hear him declare this at London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He did ſay at London, he expected there would be ſomething done at Oxford, and that he would go thither with his Horſe and Arms, and thoſe Gentlemen I named before would go with him. And he ſaid, let them begin when they would, he did not care how ſoon, his party was the greateſt party.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was that Capt. Brown? did you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, I knew him very well; he did much frequent Mr. Colledge's company; he was in the late Army againſt the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: Did you ſee him have any Piſtols?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen him carry Piſtols about him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Where, in his Pocket?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I ſaw them in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: At Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Hollaway.
sp.p: Did you ſee them in his hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I cannot tell that, he had them in the Houſe, I ſaw them there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Hollaway.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in his Silk Armour about the Parliament-Houſe, the Lobby, or any place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did you know of his delivering any marks or ſigns for perſons to be diſtinguished by?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I had as much Ribbon from him as came to forty shillings, with no Popery, no Slavery wrought in it; and he gave it me to diſtribute among my Friends in the Countrey, that they might be known by other perſons that would wear the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Where had you it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: At London, from Mr. Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Where was it to be diſtributed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Among thoſe that I knew to be Diſſenters in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Were you to come to Oxford; by agreement, with mr. Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I promiſed him to come to Oxford, and did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Well, go on, what more do you know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: At London I was once at a Coffee-Houſe with Mr. Colledge, and with ſome of the members of the Houſe of Commons; it was a little before they met; and they were earneſtly talking of the Parliament at Oxford; and of ſome diſturbance that was likely to happen here. And it was then fully agreed, and Mr. Colledg was by, that it would be the beſt way, out of every County, where the Parliament had the beſt intereſt in the people, to leave one in every County that might manage the people. This I appeal to Mr. Colledge whether it be true.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: You appeal to me. Shall I ſpeak now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: No, you will remember it by and by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of any Pictures?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray let him ſpeak that over again which he mentioned laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Being in a Coffee-Houſe with Mr. Colledge, there were ſome of the members of the Houſe of Commons by; and ſpeaking of a diſturbance that might happen here at Oxford; it was then agreed, that in every Quarter where the Parliament had the moſt intereſt in the people, they should not all come up, but ſome remain there to manage the people.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of any Pictures or Papers, have you any about you:

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, I have one thing I have received from Mr. Colledge, that is, the Letter pretended to be intercepted to Roger L'Eſtrange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, what account did he give you of it? who made it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He told me he was the Author of it himſelf, and he shewed me it in manuſcript before it was printed; and he told me, he got one Curtis or his Wife to print it; but he would never truſt them again, for they cheated him of ſome of the Gain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who was the Author did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: He himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray produce it Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: This and others he delivered to me to diſperſe.

sp.speaker: Lo. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What is it mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It is a Letter, and a great part of Fitz-Harris's Libel is taken out; it ſeems Colledge was the Author, and this is the Original of the Libel.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Did he tell you this was of his making?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he diſperſe them to any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Yes, there were ſome given to one Mr. Boſon, he had ſome at the ſame time, and Mr. Baldwin had ſome.

sp.speaker: Cl. of cr.
sp.p: Firſt Q. Whether they that talk—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray give my Lord an account what more papers and Libels he delivered to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I received one like this, I cannot ſay it was the ſame, where all the Bishops were changing their Hats for Cardinal Caps.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Where is Rary Shew; for it ſeems he hath expounded the meaning of that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe 'tis his own cutting too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I heard Mr. Colledge ſing it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: In Oxfordshire, and in Oxford Town, at my Lord Lovelace's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Where at my Lord Lovelace's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: At his Houſe in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Who were in the company there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Sir Robert Clayton, Sir Thomas Player, Mr. Rouſe, Mr. Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: You ſay you heard him in Oxford, and in Oxfordshire, and at my Lord Lovelace's, where is that?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: My Lord. Lovelace is here himſelf, and hears what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I might miſtake the County, but I heard him ſing it at Oxford Town, and at my Lord Lovelace's Houſe again.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I cannot tell the Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: How came you there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Player did invite me thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Where is it in Oxfordshire?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I cannot tell, 'tis four miles from Henly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Was my Lord at home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Now for the Cut then; Did he shew you this Cut?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, he told me he would get it printed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Was it before it was printed then that he ſung it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Who did he tell you did make it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He told me he was the Author of this Cut, and he gave me one, and we ſang it together preſently after it was printed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How did he deſcribe it to you, when he shewed it to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: That which hath the Pack on the back of it, he deſcribed to be the King; thoſe that follow him were Topham, Cooper, Hughs, and Snow; and that company of men there is the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Holloway.
sp.p: What was meant by the Pack?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: The Parliament and all his Retinue; and then here is the King in the mire again, according as 'tis repreſented in the Long—

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Ay, he goes on well. And this here is the Bishops which they thruſt into the Pack when they have got him down into the mire, and then they thruſt them all away, as it is in the Song, to hoot them away.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Did he make this explication to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Who were the All?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: King and Clergy-men and all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jefferies.
sp.p: Where was this he explained it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: At London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Holloway.
sp.p: Is there any thing relating to White-hall? what name did he give that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, he ſaid, Louſe-hall was White-hall, becauſe of its poverty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of cr. Rarp Shew.
sp.p: To the Tune of, I am a Senſleſs thing—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: This shews you what ſort of man he is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Here you ſay he explained this with the Pack at the back to be the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, he told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What did he mean by the two Faces?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: That he was half Proteſtant, and half Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Did he make any compariſon between his own party and the Kings party?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He ſaid they were but an handful to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: To his party, that was the Diſſenters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Speak that out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: That their party was but a handful to theirs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Theirs and theirs, who did he mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He meant the Diſſenters, for the Church of England he reckoned among the Papiſts.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Tell us the words he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He ſaid, his party was the true Church of England, and that which is eſtablished by Law, were but Proteſtants in maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Tell us when he made the compariſon, what words he did uſe, and upon what occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: When he perceived the King at Oxford would not yield to the Houſe of Commons, he ſaid, Let him begin as ſoon as he would, he did not care how ſoon he did begin, for their party▪ meaning the King and his party, was but an handful to him and his party, calling them the true Proteſtants, the others were Proteſtants in maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did he deſire you to do, to be aſſiſting in any thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He always deſired me to be true of that ſide, he hoped I was, and to get good Arms for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Did he in Oxford deſire this of you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No he did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: For what purpoſe did he deſire you to arm your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He ſaid the King had a deſign on the people to introduce Popery and Arbitrary Government, and he expected every day when they would begin, and the ſooner the better, he would be provided for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Was that in Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He ſpoke it in Oxford, and in the City too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Did he tell you of any that were liſted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He ſpoke of Capt. Brown, and Capt. Clinton, and Don Lewes, and abundance more he ſaid he had.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Did he tell you he had them here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, about forty of them were there he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Did he tell you of any that were liſted, in order to the coming down of the Parliament at Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Not liſted, but were intended to come down; and at Oxford he told me they were come down.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Were you in their company in Oxford here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: In the company of whom? name them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Of Capt. Brown, Don Lewes, and ſeveral others of that Gang; I know not their names, but I know their faces.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he take notice to you that they were come down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He expected there would be a riſing in Oxford, and to this purpoſe. Mr. Colledge was one that debated it at Richard's Coffee-Houſe, and it was to be carried from thence to the Kings-Head Club, Whether it were not beſt to leave a Parliament man in every County?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: This was at Richard's Coffee-Houſe in London, againſt they met here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We could give you an account of a volume of theſe things, abundance of ſcandalous Pamphlets, both Songs, Libels, and Ballads, that were made by this Gentleman, and all ſeized in his cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: But he ſung this Libel?

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: All theſe, Gentlemen, (shewing a great bundle) were to be diſperſed over England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: It was, it ſeems, expounded and ſung by the Priſoner at the Bar; he gave you the Ballad here at Oxford, you ſay, Mr. Dugdale.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No, I heard him ſing it here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Dugdale, what was the uſe was to be made of this Ballad?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Come, go to the next, we call this Evidence to shew you the malice of the man.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let me ask ſome Queſtions of Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Ay, now let the Priſoner ask his Queſtions (to do him right) before we go to another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lord, I have a word or two more about a Libel in manuſcript; that very day the Sheriffs were to be choſen, it was to be printed, and he told me the Printer duſt not print it, it was ſo dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: What was it, can you remember any part of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: No, but it was the worſt I ever heard in my life, againſt the King and Government.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Now ask him what Queſtions you will.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, when was the firſt time you gave this Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Colledge, I don't keep an account of time, I cannot give an account of time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: As near as you can, tell him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether it might be in June, I think it was.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: How long before I was taken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: It might be about the time you were taken.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray, who did you give it before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I gave it to Sir Lionel Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Where did you ſwear theſe particulars were done then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: What was done in the City, I ſwore to be done there.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What City?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: London; the ſame words were ſaid in the City of London, and over again here. I have repeated, for the moſt part, only the words you ſaid here, but more was in the City than here.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Did you ſwear then, that the words you ſwear now were ſpoken at London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: It may be we might not name Oxford then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: He ſays well; it might not be named then.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Then you did give in your Information, that I ſpoke theſe words at Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I was not examined about what was done at Oxford; but I believe I have heard you ſpeak the ſame words to me at my Lord Lovelace's, but I do not know what County that is in.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I ask you poſitively, whether you did not ſwear that what you now ſay was ſpoken at Oxford, was ſpoken at London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I did not name Oxford then.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: But did not you ſay that was done at London, that now you ſay was done here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Truly, you ſaid them both at London, and here.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Dugdale, what had you to give this your information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: Truly I can't ſay I have received the worth of a Groat.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Nor was ever promiſed any thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No, I never received any thing, nor ever was promiſed, but only what the King gave me for going down into the Countrey for my charges.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was that the ſame Allowance you had when you were Witneſs for the Popish Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Have you any other Allowance than what you had before, when you gave Evidence at my Lord Stafford's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No, nor have got all that yet neither.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: But pray obſerve my queſtion, Mr. Dugdale, and anſwer it: Did you not ſwear at London that I ſpoke theſe words there, which now you ſay I ſpoke here.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Pray obſerve, he ſays he did not then name Oxford; but in the giving of his Evidence now, he tells you a ſeries of what paſſed between London and Oxford; and I muſt tell you further, if a Treaſon be committed, and the Evidence prove it to be in two Countries, the King may chooſe which County he will proſecute and bring his Indictment in, and give in Evidence the Facts in both Counties. But you shall have your Objection to it afterwards, and we will take it into conſideration. I tell you this, that it may not ſeem to you that the Witneſſes ſpeak impertinently of what was done at London; but if nothing was done or ſaid at Oxford, then it will be taken into conſideration, you shall have it ſaved afterwards, I only him it now, that you may not think it impertinent.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordship give me leave to ſpeak one word; When he made his Affidavit before Sir Lionel Jenkins there about ſeizing the King, about the party I had, and the Arms I had provided, ought not he at the ſame time to have ſaid where I ſaid thoſe words to him? but he did ſwear then it was in London that I ſaid thoſe words to him; and coming before a Grand Jury of honeſt Gentlemen in London, they were ſo wiſe and honeſt as to do me Juſtice, and not find the Bill; ſo their deſign failing there, then they changed it to Oxford.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: You did not come to your Tryal there, if you had ſo done, then they would have asked him in particular what was ſaid at Oxford, and what at London, as 'tis now, being done in both Counties. But look you, if you will ask any particular queſtions, do, for they have other Witneſſes to produce.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, I only ask this queſtion, Whether it be not rational to think, that when he ſwore before Sir Lionel Jenkins, he should not ſwear the words were ſpoken, and things done?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: He hath ſaid the ſame words to me at my Lord Lovelace's, as I lay in Bed with him, and this I never mentioned but now in my Evidence.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What words did I ſay there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: If you muſt have them repeated, they were about the King.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: That he was a Papiſt, and deſigned Arbitrary Government.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did I ſay ſo to you at my Lord Lovelace's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, as we lay a Bed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you lye together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they were intimates.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I had not ſix words with you when you went to Bed; for you ſaid you were weary, and went aſleep preſently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I ſay you ſaid this in the morning; for we had above an hours diſcourſe when we were a Bed, and all our diſcourſe was about the Parliament and the King.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Where was it I ſaid thoſe words in Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: At Combe's coffe-houſe was one place.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was there no body by?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: No, but at the Angel-Inn there were ſeveral perſons ſtanding by.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Surely then ſome of thoſe heard the words as well as you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: It may be ſo, I am ſure many at London have been by, as Mr. Starkey by name, Mr. Boſon, Mr. Baldwin? they have rebuked you for it, and I have rebuked you too.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What words have they and you heard, and rebuked me for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: When you have been railing againſt the King, and ſaid, That he deſigned nothing but the introducing of Popery, and Arbitrary Government, and that he was a Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: He loves to hear it repeated.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What Arms did you ſee of mine in this Town?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I ſaw Piſtols; you had a caſe of Piſtols before you, and you had ſome Pocket-Piſtols.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: None but one I borrowed of you, and that you had again; had I? pray ſpeak, did you ſee any more?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: It may be there might not, but there were Pocket-Piſtols in the room, and you had them in your hand.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: He ſwore but now that he ſaw me have Pocket-Piſtols, when it was but one, and that was his own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: Heark you now, you talk of Piſtols, do you know that he had any Piſtols in his Holſters at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, he had.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Yes, I know that, I don't deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: I think a Chiſſel might have been more proper for a Joyner.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You ſay I was confederated with Capt. Brown, and other men.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You have told me that Captain Brown had agood Allowance, and it was pity he had not a better Allowance; and you would ſpeak he might have a better Allowance, for he was able to do good ſervice when the time came.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Among you.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Among whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You know there were ſeveral Gatherings among you that I was not privy to.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What do I know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You know mony was gathered many times.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: For what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You never told me particulars; it was to diſtribute ſome where, I had none of it.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He does not ſay theſe men were concerned with you, but you ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You know, Mr. Colledge▪ there were many Gathering of monies.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did I tell you there were any Gatherings for Capt. Brown?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: He ſays you told him no particulars; if you have a mind to ask him any more Queſtions, do.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, Sir George, don't interrupt me, I am here for my Life. Did I tell you there were any Gatherings for Capt. Brown?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I do not ſay for him, nor whom you diſtributed it to; but you gathered mony one among another, and you have paid mony.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I have paid mony! when, and to whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You will not deny that, you confeſſed upon your Examination that you gave a Guinny.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Sir, did you ſee me any more at Oxford, than in the Coffee-Houſe, and at that Inn, when I went out of Town, and was going home with the City-members?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Were you in my company any where, but in thoſe two places?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes I was with you at the Chequer.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you come a purpoſe to ſpeak with me, or had you any buſineſs particularly with me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Colledge, I have forgot whether I had or no, I was in the Room with you there.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Where is that Room?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I can't tell all the Rooms in that Houſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was it above ſtairs, or below?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Both above and below, two days I was there with you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was there any of this diſcourſe you ſpeak of paſſed there between us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I know I was with you in thoſe two places I mentioned before; you called me aſide to drink a Glaſs of mum, and there was none in the Room but us two at that Coffee-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Sir, you came to Town but on Friday, I think, it must be Saturday, Sunday or Monday this was, for we ſtayed no longer in Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Nay, I came to Oxford, either Wedneſday night or Thurſday morning; and I ſaw Mr. Hunt and you together the ſame day I came.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did I explain any Pictures to you at London, or owned I was the Author of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Yes, upon my Oath, you have explained Pictures to me, and there is one Picture that I have not shewed yet, which you have explained what the meaning was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: 'Tis your common Trade it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You told me you got them done.
Clerk reads, A Character of a Popiſh Succeſſor, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Holloway.
sp.p: How did he explain it to you▪ Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: I would ſee what opinion he had of the Church of England; there are ſome Church-men, what are they a doing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: They are a parcel of Tantivy-men riding to Rome; and here's the Duke of York, half man, half devil, trumpeting before them.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: You have got ſomebody to explain theſe things to you, Mr. Dugdale.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: You did it, upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Oh, fie upon you, Mr. Dugdale, conſider what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jefferies.
sp.p: All this you did explain, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: And in one place of the other Libel, the King was termed a Rogue, but they put him in by another name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: 'Tis in Rary-Shew; In the Manuſcript it was, Now, now the Rogue is down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Let me ſee it, I took notice of it, 'tis, Now, now the Gyant is down, here.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ask you, Sir, Whether the Song which you ſay was ſung at my Lord Lovelace's, and other places, was the ſame with this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: For the general it is, I can't tell for every word: You ſang it half a dozen times there, and the muſick plaid to you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ask you whether it was the ſame with this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: I can't tell for every word you ſang.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was there any body by at my explaining of theſe Pictures?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: Mr. Baldwyn was by, and reproved and corrected you, that you would be ſo open.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Was there any body by at Oxford, when you did hear me talk of Arming my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: They were walking up and down in the Barbers Shop, and I know not whether they did hear or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was that Gentleman ſworn at my Lord Stafford's Tryal, Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Yes, I was ſworn there, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he ſwear any thing on your behalf, for your credit, Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: That was by hear-ſay, Mr. Attorney, at the Tower: I know nothing of my own knowledge; but I did believe him another man than I find him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: No queſtion, or elſe you would not have truſted him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Stevens. (Which was done.) Do you give my Lord, and the Jury, an account where you found this precious Ballad.

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: The firſt draught I found in his Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser jeff.
sp.p: What, of all of them? which is it?

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: The Rary Shew, we found the firſt draught of it in his Houſe, when we came to ſearch his papers, by order of Council, and the Printer that Printed the Ballad, hath told me ſince, he had it from him—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What ſay you your ſelf? ſpeak your own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: And Mr. Atterbury was by when we ſearched the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Atterbury will tell his own ſtory.

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: I have ſeen you on Horſeback, with Holſters before you, with ſome hundreds of men after you, coming out of the Bell-ſavage Inn; they ſaid, you were going to chooſe Parliament-men: I have known you three or four years, you were Joyner to our Hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: We call you to that particular of the papers, and you run out in a ſtory of a Cock and a Bull, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Will you ask him any queſtions?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: No, only this; Do you ſwear, upon your Oath, that you found the Original in my Houſe?

sp.speaker: Stevens,
sp.p: Yes, Sir, you will ſee it with my hand to it, and ſome more of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And you found too thoſe that were printed?

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: Yes, both our names are to them, that were concerned in the ſearching of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: You found the paper in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: That is Towzer; but you have the Original of the Rary Shew?

div.stage: (It was looked for, but could not be found.)

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, obſerve, he ſwears that is an Original.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: No, no, he found the paper in your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ask about the Original of Rary Shew.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw a paper drawn with a Pencil that was like the Original.

sp.speaker: Atterbury.
sp.p: There was an Original drawn with a Pencil, upon Dutch Paper, 'tis loſt ſince, for we do not ſee it here now, which at the ſame time we found upon Colledge's Table in his Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you find an Original of that in my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Atterbury.
sp.p: Yes, we found a paper drawn with Black-lead.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, Where is it?

sp.speaker: Atterbury.
sp.p: I did ſee it, it was drawn in Black-lead, it was upon Dutch-paper, and lay upon the Table in your chamber.

sp.speaker: Stevens.
sp.p: Sure I am it was taken when we ſearched the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I am ſure you could never find the Original of any ſuch thing in my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then where is Mr. Sewel, (Who was ſworn.) Sir, did you ſee that trumpery taken?

sp.speaker: Sewell.
sp.p:
I had a Warrant to ſeize Mr. Spur, and his Brother-in-law, Mr. Colledge. So I went down to ſeize Mr. Spur, and ſearch his Houſe for ſuch papers as I should find. I could not find them in the Houſe; but I enquired of him, after I had ſearched, and
could not find them where they were; becauſe I ſaw him at Mr. Colledge's when we firſt ſearched; he denied them a pretty while, but at laſt he told me they were in the Hay-mow in the Barn. When I came there, he was balling, and told me his Wife, Colledge's Siſter had taken them down, and carried them into a room where I had ſearched before, but could not find them; and the man was angry then, ſo we run after his Wife, and found her with all theſe papers in a bag.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Are theſe the ſame papers?

sp.speaker: Sewell.
sp.p: Yes, and there were two other Cuts; the man himſelf is about the place ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. John Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Smith, do you know Mr. Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Give us an account what dealings you have had with him, where, and when; what he hath ſaid about the King; and tell us firſt whether you be intimately acquainted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p:
We were intimately acquainted. The firſt time I heard Mr. Colledge diſcourſing any thing of this nature, that is, concerning Treaſon, or any ſuch thing, was once at a Coffee-Houſe by Temple-Bar; there I met Colledge, and he told me he was invited to Dinner, and he likewiſe invited me to it. I asked him who provided the Dinner, he told me it was one Alderman VVilcox; I told him I was a ſtranger, and did not care for going: He told me I should be very welcome there, and at laſt prevailed upon me to go: And as I was going along, I asked him what the Alderman was? He told me he was a man that was as true as ſteel, and a man that would endeavour to root out Popery: Said I, that may be done eaſily, if you can but prevail with the King to paſs the Bill againſt the D. of York. No, no, ſaid he, you are miſtaken, for Rowley is as great a Papiſt as the D. of York is (now he called the King Rowley) and every way as dangerous to the Proteſtant Intereſt, as is too apparent by his Arbitrary Ruling. This was the diſcourſe between the Coffee-Houſe and the Tavern where we went to dine. When we came in, I asked Colledge again, whether the Alderman was there; he ſaid he was not there at that time: I asked him the ſecond time what kind of man he was, he ſaid he was one that lived in his Countrey-Houſe, and gave freely to ſeveral people to buy Arms and Ammunition. And I asked him to what purpoſe? and he ſaid it was to bring the King to ſubmiſſion to his people; adding thereto, that he wondred Old Rowley did not conſider how eaſily his Fathers Head came to the Block, which he doubted not would be the end of Rowley at the laſt. After this diſcourſe the Alderman came in; we dined, and every one went his own way about his own buſineſs. Mr. Colledge▪ then told me, if I would go with him to his own Houſe, I should ſee how he was prepared with Arms and Proviſion. Soon after I met with him, and he deſired me to go along and dine with him; and I did ſo, and there he did shew me his Piſtols, his Blunderbuſs, his great Sword; and he shewed me his Armour, Back and Breaſt; and he shewed me his Head-piece, which, if I am not miſtaken, was covered over with Chamlet, it was a very fine thing; and, ſaid he,
Theſe are the things which will deſtroy the pitiful Guards of Rowley, that are kept up contrary to Law and Juſtice, to ſet up Arbitrary Power and Popery.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What did I ſay, Sir, about my Armour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Thus you ſaid; It was to deſtroy Rowley's Guards (thoſe were your words) that were kept up contrary to Law and Juſtice, to ſet up Arbitrary Power and Popery. After I had dined with him, I parted with him. A little before the Parliament was to meet at Oxford, I met him again; and were diſcourſing of ſeveral things, what preparations the City were making, how they were provided with Powder and Bullets; and for his part, he would go down to Oxford, for he expected a little ſport there, upon the diviſions that were like to be between the King and Parliament. Then ſaid I to him, why, what is the matter there? Why, ſaid he, we expect that the King will ſeize upon ſome of the members, and we are as ready as he. And, ſays he, for my part, I will be there, and be one that shall ſeize him, if he ſecure any of the members, (and I believe he did go down;) ſays he, you know how the City is provided: I told him, no, not ſo well as he; but he told me all was very well. After he came up again, I met him another time, and he told me, he went down in expectation of ſome ſport; but Old Rowley was afraid, like his Grand-father Jamy, and ſo ran away like to beshit himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Did he ſay, If he had not ran away, he would have ſeized him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He ſaid nothing of that, but before, he ſaid, He would be one of them should ſeize him, if he ſeized any of the members. After this he told me, that Fitz-Gerald and he had had a quarrel at the Parliament-door of the Houſe of Lords at Oxford; that Fitz-Gerald had called him Rogue; and, ſaid he, Fitz-Gerald made my Noſe bleed; but before long, I hope to ſee a great deal more Blood shed for the cauſe. After this again, when there was a diſcourſe of diſarming the City, that my Lord Feverſham was to come to do it, he told me, he was well provided, and if Feversham, or any man, nay Rowley himſelf should attempt any ſuch thing, he would be the death of him, before any man should ſeize upon his Arms.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Did he diſcourſe any thing to you about Arms to provide your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, he did, I had an Armour from him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He did deſire me to get Arms, for I did not know how ſoon I might make uſe of them. I had an Armour from him upon trial; he ſaid it coſt him 30 or 40 s. I had it upon trial, but it was too big for me, ſo I gave it him back, and bought a new one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Did he tell you to what purpoſe you should arm your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: No, he did not name any purpoſe, but he told me I did not know how ſoon I might make uſe of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you about any one's ſeizing the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He told me the Parliament were agreed to ſecure the King, and that in order to it, all Parliament-men came very well armed, and accompanied with arms and men; and he told me of a great man that had notice from all the Gentlemen of England how well they came armed.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: What did he ſay of himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He would be one that should ſecure the King, if he ſeized any of the members.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: When he had been there, what did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: If they had had any work, he was ready provided for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But pray tell us again what he ſaid of the Kings running away?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: He ſaid Rowley was afraid, like his Grand-father Jumy, and ran away ready to beshit himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: If you have done with him, Mr. Attorney, let the Priſoner ask him what Queſtions he will.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Mr. Smith, Where was this diſcourſe I had with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Which do you mean, the former part or the latter?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: The firſt diſcourſe you talk of, what I told you going to Mr. Wilcox's to dinner, and when it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: You know beſt when it was, I can't exactly remember the time, but you know 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: As we went along thither we had the firſt part of it, and when we came thither, you and I talked till Alderman Wilcox came in; and you and I were alone together, and ſeveral perſons that were there, were drawn into Cabals, two by two.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: In the room where we dined; and you know there was a little room by, where ſome were drinking a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You ſay, by two and two the company were drawn into Cabals.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I tell you moſt of them were in Cabals, two and two together, only thoſe two Gentlemen that belonged to the Alderman went up and down, and gave Wine.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Is it for this man to ask me, my Lord, ſuch a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Yes, anſwer him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You were a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, what then? and I am in Orders now.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: That was from the Church of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes and that is a good Ordination: I came in voluntarily to diſcover the Popish Plot, and was no Pentioner, nor received any Sallary from the King. I have ſpent ſeveral pounds, ſeveral ſcores of pounds, but received no recompence. And I was the Darling at one time all over the City, when I did adhere to what they would have me to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Did not you ſwear againſt my Lord Stafford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were not you a Witneſs, Mr. Smith, at my Lord Stafford's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
Colledge.
sp.p: Pray hear me Sir, if you pleaſe; the firſt diſcourſe that you ſpeak of about Mr. Wilcox's being a good man for the Cauſe, and contributing mony, this was when we were at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: This was that day when we went to dinner with him, you know it very well.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Where were the other Diſcourſes I had with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Which part of them?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: When I came from Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: By the Ditch ſide, by your own Houſe; I have two or three to prove it, we were an hour or two diſcourſing together about this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What buſineſs?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He tells you of two Diſcourſes, one before you went to Oxford, and one after you came from thence.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He does ſay, that I diſcourſed him about our coming down hither to Oxford, that the Parliament would ſecure the King, and that I would be one of them that ſhould ſeize him, and this was at the time when we dined with Alderman Wilcox.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Not ſo, he ſays after that time, and before you went to Oxford, he had ſuch a diſcourſe with you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, ſo it was.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: And does he ſpeak of another time when I ſhewed him the Back, Breaſt and Arms?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: But he ſaid, I diſcourſed then, that the City was provided with Arms, and that the Parliament were reſolved to bring the King to ſubmisſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: When I was in the Houſe with him, he then ſaid Mr. Wilcox gave Mony to provide Arms: I asked for what? he ſaid, it was to bring the King to ſubmiſſion to his People; and then he added, he admired that Rowley did not remeber how eaſily his Fathers Head came to the Block; and he doubted not but that would be the end of him too.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He ſpake of ſeveral times you know.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I do not know one word of it, nor can diſtinguiſh the times: But, Mr. Smith the last diſcourſe you ſay about Oxford buſineſs, was by the Ditch ſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: The Diſcourſe about bringing the King to ſubmiſſion, was in the way as you went to dinner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: The laſt Diſcourſe when you returned from Oxford, was by the Ditch ſide; but both before and after you ſpake to me at that place about this deſign of bringing the King to ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: You ſaid it was at Wilcox's at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: You miſtook him then.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Nay, Sir George, you took him not right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: I have taken him right I aſſure you, and you shall ſee it by and by.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: He is the falſeſt man that ever ſpoke with a tongue.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
Swear Bryan Haynes. (which was done. Tell my Lord, and the Jury, whether you know this Gentleman, what converſe you have had with him, and
what diſcourſe he hath had with you. Apply your ſelf to Mr. Colledges buſineſs only.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe he will not deny but that he knows very well; I have been acquainted with him ever ſince March laſt, before the ſitting of the Parliament at Oxford. My Lord, there was a Warrant againſt me for High Treaſon; and I made my application to Mr. Colledge, and deſired him to go to a certain Perſon of Honour in England, and ask his advice, whether I might ſupercede the Warrant by putting in Bayl, and carry the Supercedeas in my pocket: Mr. Colledge told me he would go to this perſon of Honour, for he would do nothing of his own head; and he bid me come to him the next day. My Lord, I came to Mr. Colledge the very next day, and I met him at his Houſe, and I asked him what was the reſult, and what advice he had from that perſon of Quality; he bid me be of good chear, that the Parliament would be, and ſit at Oxford ſoon; that I should not value the King a pin; for, ſaid he, the King is in a worſe condition than you or I; for you shall ſee, ſaid he, he shall be called to an account for all his Actions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Who should?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: The King; for all the world may ſee, ſays he, that he does reſolve to bring in Arbitrary Power and Popery: And, ſaid he, unleſs he will let the Parliament ſit at Oxford, ſince he hath called them together, and put the people to charges in chuſing of them, and them in coming down, we will ſeize him at Oxford, and bring him to the Block, as we did the Logger-head his Father. The Parliament shall ſit at Guildhall, and adjuſt the Grievances of the Subject, and of the Nation. And you shall ſee, ſaid he, that no King of his Race shall ever reign in England after him.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Where was this he ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: At his own Houſe I met him; and he and I did walk all along from his own Houſe, over the Bridge that is againſt Bridewel, and ſo went all along till we came to the Hercules-Pillars, and we had ſome diſcourſe there; we went up one pair of ſtairs and called for Beef; and all this diſcourſe was in that very place of the Hercules-Pillars.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of any Arms he had, and for what?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: But, Sir, ſaid I to Mr. Colledge, how can this be done, 'tis a thing impoſſible. You pretend, you ſay, to the Duke of Monmouth, that he is a fine Prince, and ſtands up for the Proteſtant Intereſt: Alas, ſaid he, we make an Idol of him to adumbrate our Actions, for fear we should be diſcovered. Do you think the wiſe people of England shall ever make a Baſtard upon Record King of England: No, ſaid he, for though we praiſe his Actions, yet we cannot endure him, becauſe he is againſt his own Father. But, ſaid he, further, unleſs the King do expel from his Council the Earl of Clarindon, cunning Lory Hide, the Earl of Hallifax, that great Turn-coat Rogue, that was before ſo much againſt the Papiſts, a Raſcal, we shall ſee him hang'd, and all the Tory Counſellors; except the King do it, we will make England too hot for him.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Who did I ſay this to, to you?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Yes, to me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, how could this be posſible?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Yes, you knew my condition; and I intimated to you at that time, That I was as much for Treaſon and Villany as you: But then ſaid I to him, how can this be done? Here you have neither Officers, nor men of experience, nor men of knowledge; nor you have no Ammunition, Sea-port Towns, nor Ships. And beſides, the King, ſaid I, hath a great party in the Land, and the Duke of York likewiſe; and for all the men of Eſtates, and the ancient Gentlemen, they will not be diſturbed, and to quit their Eaſe for a civil War. Oh, ſays he, you are miſtaken, for we have in the City 1500 Barrels of Powder, and we have 100000 men ready at an hours warning; and we have ordered every thing in a due method againſt the ſitting of the Parliament at Oxford; and you shall ſee England the moſt glorious Nation in the World, when we have cut off that beaſtly Fellow Rowley; and ſpeaking of the King, he ſaid, He came of the Race of Buggerers, for his Grandfather, King James, buggered the old Duke of Buckingham; and he called him Captain, and ſometimes the King, and ſometimes Rowley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: This was pure Proteſtant diſcourſe upon my word.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Then he railed at Judge Pemberton; and, ſaid he, let him try Fitz-Harris if he dare; I shall ſee him go to Tyburn for it, I hope, a Turn-coat Rogue. He was for the Plot whilſt he was a puiſne Judge, but now he is Chief Juſtice, he is the greateſt Rogue in the world. He is like one of the Penſioners in the long Parliament. So one day I went along with Mrs. Fitz-Harris, and Mr. Ivy, and he ſent a man to me, and deſired me to come to the Hog in Armor; thither we came, and met him, and went to his Lodgings, and there we dined. Then they made ſome perſons of Honour believe, that I was a perſon ſo and ſo qualified, and was brim full of the Plot; and he would put me upon charging the King with the firing of London, and the murder of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, and ſaid he, ſuch and ſuch Lords shall live and die by you; and beſides, ſaid he, you need not fear, England shall eſpouſe your Cauſe. But, ſaid I, the Law is like the Spiders Web, that catches the little Flies, but the great Flies run through the Net, and make their eſcape; ſo 'tis with theſe Lords, they put you and me on the danger of acting; and when they get off by intereſt, a Jury of Twelve men will hang us by the Neck, and ſo I should perish, whilſt others triumphed, and only be a martyr for the Phanaticks. So in diſcourſe we were talking of the Libel of Fitz-Harris; The Devil take me, ſaid he, every individual word is as true as God is in Heaven; and ſaid he, if you do not joyn with Fitz-Harris in his Evidence, and charge the King home, you are the baſeſt fellow in the world, for he makes you ſlaves and beggars, and would make all the world ſo; and 'tis a kind of charity to charge him home, that we may be rid of ſuch a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Mr. Colledge, if you will ask him any Queſtions, you may.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, the thing ſpeaks it; he is not to be talked withal; Is it probable I should talk to an Irish-man that does not underſtand ſenſe?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: 'Tis better to be an honeſt Irish-man than an English Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: He does it but to put you into a heat, don't be paſſionate with him.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: No, I am not, I thank God he hath not put me into an heat.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Where was this diſcourſe about ſuperceding your Warrant?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: At London.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: It was before the Parliament ſate at Oxon.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I can't tell poſitively to an hour or a day.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What month as near as you can?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: It was in the month of March.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Had you ever ſeen me before?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Can you deny that?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ask you whether you have or no?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen you in the Coffee-Houſes bawling againſt the Government.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Were you an intimate acquaintance of his before March laſt?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: No intimate acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Then this is the firſt time you diſcourſed with me.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Oh, no, my Lord. One and I fell out at the Queens-Head Tavern at Temple-Bar, and he ſet me upon the buſineſs, and John Macnamarra and others, and truly I did the buſineſs for him: For we fell out, and did box, and our Swords were taken from us, and I went to John Macnamarra, and told him, yonder is ſuch a man at ſuch a place, now you may ſeize upon him.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: One Richard Ponre.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He belonged to my Lord Tyrone, I think, there were Warrants to take him. Do you ſay I ſet you upon that?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Yes, you were with me the night before, and Captain Browne, and they gave us a Signal, a blue Ribband to diſtinguish that we were Proteſtants from the Bishops men.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: When were you to make uſe of it?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: When the King was ſeized.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Well, go on, have you any more?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: But, my Lord, further, after he came from Oxon. I met him, and ſaid I, Where are now all your cracks and brags? now you ſee the King hath made a fool of you; now you know not what you would have done. Says he, what would you have us do? We have not done with him yet: For, ſaid he, no ſervant, no man living did know whether he would Diſſolve the Parliament that day. I was that very nick of time at the Lobby of the Lords-Houſe, and there was a man came in with a Gown under his arm, and every one looked upon him to be a Taylor, and no body did ſuſpect, no, not his intimateſt Friends, except it were Fitz-Gerald, that he would Diſſolve the Parliament that day; but preſently he puts on his Robes, and ſends away for the Houſe of Commons; and when he had Diſſolved them, before ever the Houſe could get down, he took Coach and went away, otherwiſe the Parliament had been too hard for him; for there was never a Parliament-man but had divers armed men to wait on him, and I had my Blunderbuſs and my man to wait upon me. But well, ſaid he, there is a God above will rule all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Turbervile.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, I deſire to ask him ſome queſtions. You ſay the firſt time that I ſaw you, you had this diſcourſe with me.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Do not uſe Tautologies, 'tis not the firſt time I have been examined, I know how to ſpeak as well as you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Anſwer my Queſtion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: You know it was after I had made Affidavit before the Recorder of London, a copy of which was carried to that Noble-man; And you came from him, and returned me his thanks, and told me it was the beſt ſervice I could do him. I would not trouble the Court with circumſtantial things; and you cold me I ſhould be gratified not only in my own property, but a reward for me and my heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I made Affidavit before the Recorder of London.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Concerning one Fitz-Gerald.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is it to this matter?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: No, nothing at all.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Let him ask any queſtions, what he will.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ask when it was the firſt time you were acquainted with me ſo much, as to know me well?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: As to the firſt time of intimacy, here is Macnamarra will take his corporal Oath that I was as well acquainted with him as any one in the World.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray anſwer me, Sir; When was the firſt time I talked to you?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: The firſt intimate acquaintance we had, was when you put me upon the deſign about Fitz-Gerald.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray Sir, you go too faſt already, as you are ſtill gallopping; where was this diſcourſe about his Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I told you before.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I went to you after the Affidavit was made, and told you there was a Warrant out after me, and deſired you to go to That Noble-man, and deſire his advice what I might do, or whether I might ſuperſede the Warrant. You told me you could do nothing without advice, and you would go and adviſe with That Noble-man.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, here is Mr. Turbervile come in, they will over-hear one another, pray let me have fair play for my life. (whereupon Turbervile withdrew.)

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Can't you anſwer him? When was the firſt time you came acquainted with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: When was the firſt diſcourſe you had with him?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: In April laſt.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You ſay it was before the Sitting of the Parliament, and that was in March.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I meant in March.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: So indeed you ſaid at firſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: He never did ſay the day of the Month, nor the Month neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: How long was it before the Sitting of the Parliament?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Mr. Jones, truely I do not remember preciſely how long it was before the ſitting of the Parliament, but I am ſure it was before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: I did take it that he ſaid it was before the ſitting of the Parliament, and now he ſays, in the month of March. Pray at that time he talked to you, did not he tell you of the ſitting of the Parliament, and that they would ſtand by you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He hath ſaid it already, you need not direct him, Sir George, he goes faſt enough. But you ſay, Sir, the firſt time I ever was acquainted with you was in March, then Gentlemen conſider whether it be probable that at that time I ſhould diſcourſe to him after this manner.

sp.speaker: L. c. juſt.
sp.p: No, I will tell you what he ſays, He ſaid the firſt time he was intimately acquainted with you, was in March, he ſaid he had before ſeen you in Coffee-Houſes, and he is ſure it was before the ſitting of the Parliament; for he tells you the diſcourſe you had, and by that diſcourſe it appears, it related to a Parliament that was afterwards to ſit. And then, to give you a more particular circumſtance, he ſays that you put him upon the making of the Affidavit about Fitz-Gerald, and ſo you came acquainted.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Ask Mr. Attorney. My Lord, that day he was taken and carried to Whitehall before the Secretary of State; He ſaid, I do not know who it ſhould be that should accuſe me, I believe it is Ivy; as for Haynes, he was taken t'other day, he was an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You ſay I deſired you to make an Affidavit, was it after that or before I had that diſcourſe with you?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: It was after. For I came and deſired you to go to ſuch a perſon of Quality, and you went to him and adviſed with him; and then the next morning ſuch diſcourſe as I told your Lordship and the whole Court of, he told me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did I ſpeak theſe Treaſonable words after the Affidavit made?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: You ſaid I muſt make ſuch an Affidavit concerning Fitz-Gerald.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: But was this Treaſonable diſcourſe before you made the Affidavit, or after?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: After the Affidavit made you told me this: when I came to his Houſe, and from thence we went to the Hercules-Pillars.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more Queſtions, Mr. Colledge?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you ever ſpeak with me in your life before Macnamarra did call me out of the Coffe-Houſe to go along with you, where you would diſcover a Deſign againſt my Lord Shaftsbury's Life?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: I told you I never had any intimate acquaintance with you in my life before, nor did I ever ſpeak with you before.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: When was that diſcourſe, I ask you once again?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: After the Affidavit made.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: That night?

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Within a week or thereabouts after the Affidavit made.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Edward Turbervile. But Mr. Haynes, I would ask you one Queſtion, Did he deliver you any Ribband as a mark of diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Haynes.
sp.p: Yes, here it is.

div.stage: (and it was ſhewed to the Court.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Turbervile will you tell my Lord and the Jury what Diſcourſe you had with Mr. Colledge, and where, and when.

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: When the Parliament ſat at Oxon. about the middle of the week, I cant be poſitive in the day, but I think it was in the middle of the week I dined with Mr. Colledge, Captain Brown and Don Lewes Clerk of Derby-Houſe, at the Chequer Inn. After Dinner Don Lewes went out about his own buſineſs, and Captain Brown went to ſleep; Mr. Colledge and I fell talking of the Times, and I was obſerving, I thought the Parliament was not a long lived Parliament. Said he, there is no good to be expected from the King; for he and all his Family are Papiſts, and have ever been ſuch, you know it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Nay don't appeal to him.

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: Said I, the King will offer ſome thing or other by way of ſurprize to the Parliament, Said he, I would he would begin; but if he do not, we will begin with him and ſeize him; for there are ſeveral brave Fellows about this Town that will ſecure him till we have thoſe terms that we expect from him.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: At the Chequer Inn in Oxon.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What ſaid he further?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: He ſaid he had got a Caſe of Piſtols, and a very good Sword, and a Velvet Cap; and I can't be poſitive he had Armour on, but I believe he had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he tell you he came down for that purpoſe to ſeize the King?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, and he gave me a piece of blew Ribband to put upon my Hat, he had a great quantity of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was that for?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: To be a diſtinction if there should be any diſturbance when the thing should be done.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What thing done?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: I knew nothing but of your telling me of it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: At the Chequer Inn in Oxon. M. Colledge. You talk much and can't remember all you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What did he diſcourſe to you about Arms and an Horſe.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: I told him I had never an Horſe, and nothing but a Caſe of Piſtols; he bid me I should not trouble my ſelf, for he would get me an Horſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: To carry on your deſign, I know not what it was, but by your words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Tell what he ſaid of it at the Chequer Inn.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: He ſaid there was a Deſign to ſeize the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he deſire you to be one of them.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: He did deſire me to be ready to aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: And how much of that Ribband had he, pray?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: A very great quantity, 40 or 50 Yards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Turbervile will you give your Evidence over again, and let Mr. Colledge attend to it.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: When the Parliament ſat at Oxon. about the middle of the week, I cannot be poſitive to a day; I believe it was either Wedneſday or Thurſday I dined with Mr. Colledge, Captain Brown, and Don Lewes, who was formerly Clerk of Derby-Houſe. Don Lewes after dinner went out, and Capt. Browne laid him down on the bed, and Mr. Colledge and I fell a talking of the Times, and I told him, I thought this Parliament was no long-lived Parliament. Upon which Colledge told me the King and all his Family were Papiſts, and there was no good to be expected from him. Then I replyed, the King would perhaps ſurprize the Parliament, or uſe ſome ſtratagem to bring them to his terms. Said Mr. Colledge again, I would he would begin; but if he do not, we will ſecure him till he comes to thoſe terms we would have from him; for here are ſeveral brave Fellows, and many more are coming down that will joyn with it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he name any one?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: No indeed, he did not; he himſelf had a caſe of Piſtols, a Sword, and I believe he might have his Armour on.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did I diſcourſe who were to joyn with me?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: No, Mr. Colledge, you did not name any body to me, but Captain Browne was with you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you examined in my Lord Staffords Tryal?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: Yes I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was this Gentleman ſworn to your Reputation there?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: No, not to mine.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray how come we to talk of ſuch things, what occaſion was there that I ſhould talk Treaſon of the King to you, was there any body beſides us two there.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: No, Capt. Browne was gone to ſleep, and Lewes was gone out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It was not at dinner that you talked ſo, Mr. Colledge, he ſays.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Had they been at dinner with us there?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: Yes, and we had a Legg of boyled mutton to dinner.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you ſtay after dinner?

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: Yes, and I lay with you afterwards upon the bed.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I thought you had ſaid Capt. Browne went to ſleep there.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: Yes, but he was gone too, when we laid down together.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: God forgive you, I can ſay no more, I never ſpoke one word of any ſuch diſcourſe in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervile, when did you give in this Information againſt me?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: I gave it to the Grand Jury.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Not before?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: Truly I can't well tell, I believe it was a day or two before I came to Oxon.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why did you make it then, and not before?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: I'll tell you the occaſion. Mr. Dugdale told me the Grand Jury of London would not find the Bill; I did admire at it extremely; for I thought every one that converſed with him might be an Evidence againſt him; he was always ſo very lavish againſt the King and the Government. So then Colonel Warcupp came to me, and took my Depoſitions, and then I came for Oxford.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: VVhat was the reaſon you did not diſcover this Treaſon before?

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: There was no reaſon for it, it was not neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: You were not agreed then.

sp.speaker: Turbervile.
sp.p: There was no agreement in the caſe, there needs nothing of that I think; but I am not obliged to give you an account of it.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: God forgive you, Mr. Turbervile.

sp.speaker: Turberv.
sp.p: And you too, Mr. Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then call Sir VVilliam Jennings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, if you pleaſe, till he comes, I will acquaint my Lord here is a Gentleman that hath not yet been taken notice of, one Mr. Maſters, that is pretty well known to Mr. Colledge; now he is a man, he muſt acknowledge, of an undoubted Reputation, and I deſire he may give your Lordship and the Jury an account what he knows of the Priſoner; becauſe he is ſo curious for English-men, we have brought him an English-man of a very good repute.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, I am charged with Treaſon in this Indictment; here are a great many things made uſe of that ſerve only to amuſe the Jury, I can conjecture nothing elſe they are brought for; I deſire to know whether the Pictures produced are part of the Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Stay till the Evidence is given▪ and we will hear what you can ſay at large when you come to ſumm up your Defence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, will you be pleaſed to hear this Gentleman. He will tell you what diſcourſe he hath had with the Priſoner at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. Maſters.
sp.p:
Mr. Colledge and I have been acquainted for a great many years; and we have often diſcourſed. I have told him of his being ſo violent as he hath been ſeveral times. But a little before the Parliament at Oxon. about Chriſtmaſs laſt, after the Parliament at VVeſtminſter, at Mr. Charlton's Shop the Woollen-Draper in Paul's Church-yard, we were diſcourſing together about the Government, and he was juſtifying of the late long Parliaments Actions in 40; and he ſaid, That Parliament was as good a Parliament as ever was choſen in the Nation. Said I, I wonder how you have
the impudence to juſtify their Proceedings, that raiſed the Rebellion againſt the King, and cut off his Head. Said he, they did nothing but what they had juſt cauſe for, and the Parliament that ſate laſt at VVeſtminſter was of their opinion, and ſo you would have ſeen it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What did he ſay of the Parliament ſince?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maſters.
sp.p: He ſaid the Parliament that ſate laſt at VVeſtminſter was of the ſame opinion that that Parliament was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Pray afterwards, what diſcourſe had you about his Colonelship?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maſters.
sp.p: We were talking at Guild-Hall that day the Common-Council was, the 13th. of May, as near as I remember; ſo I came to him, How now, Colonel Colledge, ſaid I, what do you make this buſtle for? You miſtook me, and ſaid, Couſin, how long have you and I been Couſins? nay prithee, ſaid I, 'tis not yet come to that, to own Kindred between us, I only called you Colonel in jeſt; Marry mock not, ſaid he, I may be one in a little time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Have you any thing to ask Mr. Maſters? you know he is your old acquaintance, you know him well.

sp.speaker: Mr. jones.
sp.p: What is it that you know concerning Mr. Colledge at Oxford, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir VVilliam Jennings.
sp.p: My Lord, the firſt time that I heard any thing of Mr. Colledge, was, there was ſome company looking upon a Picture, for I knew him not, nor never had any word of diſcourſe with him in my life, any more then ſeeing him in a publick Coffee-Houſe. But there was a Picture looking on by 7 or 8 or 10 people, I believe, more or leſs, and I coming and crowding in my Head amongſt the reſt, looked upon this Picture. After the crowd was over, Mr. Colledge takes a Picture out of his Pocket; and, ſaid he, I will give you one of them, if you will. So he gives me a Picture; which Picture, if I could ſee, I could tell what it was; it was written Mac a top, and there were ſeveral Figures in it.

This is one of the ſame that I had of him, and I had not had it long in my cuſtody, but meeting with Juſtice VVarcupp, I shewed it him, who bid me give it him, and ſo I did. The next thing I did ſee Mr. Colledge do, that was in the coffee-houſe, not the ſame day, but another time: I ſaw him bring in a parcel of blue Ribband which was wrought, and theſe words eight times wrought in it, twice wrought in every quarter of a yard, No Popery, no Slavery. I ſaw him ••• l to a member of Parliament, as I took him to be, a yard of that Ribband for 2 s. and truly I was thinking he would ask me to but ſome too, and I ſaw that Gentleman (I took him to be a Parliament-man) take this Ribband and tye it upon his Sword. As to the other thing I have to ſay of Mr. Colledge, that very day the Parliament was diſſolved he had been in a quarrel, as he told me, with Fitz-Gerald, and I was ſtanding in the School-Houſe yard, and he comes directly to me without my ſpeaking to him or any thing; but he comes and tells me Fitz-Gerald had ſpit in his face, and, ſaid he, I ſpit in his face again; ſo we went to loggerheads together,
I think that was the word, or Fiſty-cuffs. So, ſaid I, Mr. Colledge, your Noſe bleeds; he takes his Handkerchief out of his Pocket and wipes his Noſe, and ſaid, I have loſt the firſt Blood in the Cauſe, but it will not be long before more be loſt.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Sir William Jennings.
sp.p: In the School-houſe Yard at Oxon. I never diſcourſed with him afterwards till I met him in London in Fleet-ſtreet one Sunday in the afternoon, and I remember Captain Creſcett was along with me. And when he came up to me, How now, ſaid I, honeſt Joyner? Says he, you call me honeſt Joyner, ſome call me Rogue and Raſcal, and I have been beating ſome of them; ſo that I believe they will be aware of it. So I told Captain Creſcett I never met this man but he was always in a Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Was it on a Sunday that I told you I had been beating of ſomebody?

sp.speaker: Sir. Will. jenn.
sp.p: You told me ſo, Captain Creſcett was by.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I remember I met you, but I did not tell you I had been then beating any one. But pray, Sir William, when I met you after the Parliament was Diſſolved, and Fitz-Gerald and I had quarrell'd, did I ſay, That I had loſt the firſt blood in the Cauſe, but it would not be long e're more were loſt.
