sp.p: This I do ſay, I would not ſpeak more nor leſs than the truth, he did not deny, but he had heard Colledge ſpeak thoſe words he ſwore, but he did not believe him, and I think Mr. Smith hath ſaid that at another time before Mr. Gardner.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: If he knew of no Proteſtant Plot, it was very unlikely that I ſhould attempt ſuch a thing my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. S.
sp.p: My Lord, I find Mr. Smith hath been very paſſionate and very inveterate of late againſt other men that he hath given me a very good report of before; And when I was talking of this, I was ſaying, if it be true that people ſay of you, a man goes in danger of his life to converſe with you. Mr. Smith, ſaid he, I do not care for all the men between Wapping and Charing-croſs, there is never a man that will forbear my company, but would do or ſay as much as Colledge hath done or ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Smith.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and I ſay ſo ſtill.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: 'Tis a contradiction in it ſelf, That there ſhould be ſuch a deſign and none but my ſelf to do it. God my righteous Judge knows my innocency.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: You might ſay thoſe words in hopes they would be of your party and made ſo by your Libels and poyſonous Pictures.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Come, call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p:
Call Mr. Tho. Gardner. But my Lord, how likely is it that I ſhould ſay,
That I would ſeize the King, when he it ſeems ſays, he did not believe there was one man to ſtand by me?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What ſay you to this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I never ſaw him in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gardner.
sp.p: Nor I you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I know not three of all that come here.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Well, will you ask him any thing?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, do you know Mr. Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gardner.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What do you know of him? Can you ſay any thing concerning this matter that is ſworn againſt of Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gardner.
sp.p: My Lord, this day fortnight I think it was, Mr. S. Smith, the Gentleman that was juſt now up before me, ſent for me to the Rummer in Queen-ſtreet to drink a glaſs of Wine, where, when I came, I found him and Mr. J. Smith that is here, whom they call Narrative Smith, talking very briskly concerning one Colledge, I ſuppoſe that is the Gentleman, and the Jury that acquitted him, and he ſaid that two or three of the Jury-men were Raſcals and Villains; and, ſays he, they talk up and down the Town as if I did intend to Sham the Popish Plot, and to make a Proteſtant Plot; which, ſaid he, I vow to God, and I will juſtifie it before God, and all the World, that I know of no Proteſtant Plot, nor is there any Proteſtant concerned in a Plot to my knowledge, but this Colledge, and upon his Tryal I believe he will be made appear to be more a Papiſt than a Proteſtant; but ſays Mr. Smith to him, Now you are known to be a Witneſs in this caſe, it will be a dangerous thing for a man to converſe with you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Will it be now known that I am a Papiſt? No man could ever ſay ſo in this World.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gardner.
sp.p: Says he, I care not what all the world ſays of me, and I do not value all the men from Wapping to Charing-Croſs, but that man that will shun my company, will ſay and do as much to the King as Colledge hath done. But then I was ſaying, methinks it ſeems an improbable thing, that ſuch a man as Colledge should ſeize upon the King, or provide 1500 Barrels of Powder, and thoſe other things. Upon my word, ſaid he, with ſome paſſion, clapping his hand upon his breaſt, when Mr. Colledge did ſay it, I did not believe a word of it; and upon my Faith I believe Colledge himſelf did not believe it when he told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Do you know any thing more, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gardner.
sp.p: No indeed, Mr. Colledge.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Call Dr. Oates again

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to him?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, Dr. Oates, Mr. Smith charges me that I should ſpeak ſome treaſonable words that time that Alderman Wilcox gave you a Treat at the Crown-Tavern, you were there, and pray how long ago was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p:
My Lord, I heard Mr. Smith ſpeaking of it at the Old-Bailey, and if you pleaſe to take notice, it was thus; This Summer was twelve-month, or I am ſure a great
while before Chriſtmas the Alderman had invited me ſeveral times to give me a Treat, and I had not time, other buſineſs calling me off, but finding a time, I ſent him word I would come and ſee him. He ſaid he was a Brewer and troubled at home with cuſtomers, but he would give me a Dinner at the Crown Tavern without Temple-Bar, that was the place fixed upon; there was Mr. Smith the Counſellor, who had been ſerviceable to me in ſeveral inſtances, I did get him to go along with me, and Mr. Colledge was with us, and I heard Smith ſwearing at the Old Baily, that Mr. Colledge and he had diſcourſe from the Rainbow Coffee-Houſe where we met, and went together.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: There I was invited by Alderman Wilcox.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: But my Lord, I will tell my ſtory, I am not to tell Mr. Smiths; Colledge did tell me he was invited; ſaid I, You shall be welcome as far as I can make you welcome. So Colledge ahd I went together from the Rainbow Coffe-Houſe to the Crown Tavern: Now indeed Colledge was very pleaſant and merry, and as I think, the diſcourſe betwixt the Rainbow Coffee-Houſe and the Tavern was betwixt Mr. Colledge and me; for Mr. Smith ſtayed ſomewhat behind or walked before, I cannot tell which: When we came to the Crown Tavern we did, to divert our ſelves till Dinner came up, enter into a Philoſophical diſcourſe with one Mr. Savage, who was formerly a Romiſh Prieſt, but this Savage is ſince pardoned by the King and is a member of the Church of England, and hath been Profeſſor of Divinity and Philoſophy beyond Sea. This as I remember was the diſcourſe before we dined till we went to dinner, it was concerning the Exiſtence of God whether that could be proved by natural demonſtration, and whether or no the Soul was immortal: my Lord, after dinner Smith went away; I did not hear the leaſt diſcourſe of any ſuch thing as he ſpeaks of, and Mr. Smith and Colledge had no diſcourſe in my hearing from the Coffee-Houſe to the Tavern; and when we were in the Tavern we did diſcourſe about thoſe two Points. Counſellor Smith, my Lord, will juſtifie a great deal of this, and my Brother too, who was with us. But when I heard Mr. Smith ſwear as he did about this matter at the Old Baily, I did really, my Lord, in my conſcience look upon him to be forſworn in that particular.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: And he does ſwear you are out in this.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: If your Lordship pleaſe he ſpeaks of Mr. Wilcox to be a man that contributed money to buy Arms, Powder and Shot, I think Sir George Jefferies knows Alderman Wilcox is a man of another employment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Sir George Jefferies does not intend to be an Evidence I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not deſire Sir George Jefferies to be an Evidence for me, I had Credit in Parliaments, and Sir George had Diſgrace in one of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Your Servant Doctor, you are a witty man and a Philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Call Mr. Thomas Smith.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What would you ask of him now?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
Counſellor Smith, here is John Smith, or Narrative Smith, which you pleaſe to call him, hath charged me with ſpeaking Treaſon at our going to dinner at Mr.
Wilcox's, I remember you were there, and I think you and I, and Dr. Oates and his Brother, and Mr. Godwin Wharton went together; I did tell Mr. Smith of it, but I did not ſtir a ſtep out of the Coffee-houſe with him, but went away before him: How long ago is it ſince we had that Dinner?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordship pleaſe, I do very well remember Mr. Alderman VVilcox, ſo they called him, did deſire to give Dr. Oates a Treat, with ſome other of his Friends, at the Crown-Tavern without Temple-Bar; but really, my Lord, as to the certain time I do not remember it, but to my beſt remembrance, my Lord, it was before Chriſtmaſs laſt, and ſome time before Chriſtmaſs laſt. And, my Lord, I was there all the time, Mr. Smith was at that time ſomewhat a ſtranger to me, ſomething I had heard of his name, and I did ſtay there all the while: I remember Mr. Alderman VVilcox was to go out of Town that day; and truly, as to any thing of matter of Treaſon, or Treaſonable words; or any thing tending towards it; I am confident nothing was, or could be ſpoken, and the room was a very ſmall room, and our company did fill it up, and the Table was ſo big, that there was little more than for the Servitors to go about, ſo that any man might eaſily hear from the one end of the room to the other. I remember there was ſome diſcourſe betwixt Dr. Oates and Mr. Savage, who I think hath been a Jeſuit, and it was about ſome points of Philoſophy and Divinity; but for Treaſon, I do not remember the leaſt of it, and I am confident Colledge ſaid not any ſuch thing at that time, and my reaſon is this; I very well remember Mr. Colledge did ſet himſelf down upon one ſide of the Table, and fell aſleep, and unleſs he talked Treaſon in his ſleep, there could not be any ſuch thing ſaid, and if it had been ſaid, it would have been heard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Smith, did you never hear Mr. Colledge ſpeak any ill words of the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: Never in my life: And if I were now to take the Sacrament upon it, I could ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: You uſed to converſe with him, Mr. Smith, did he never ſay any thing like it to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: Good Mr. Serjeant, you know I can take the Sacrament; pray let us have no reflections.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Who did reflect upon you, I did not reflect upon you.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Mr. Smith, did he never deliver you any of thoſe Pictures?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: No Sir, he never did.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Good Sir George don't reflect upon my Evidence. It ſeems Smith is miſtaken in the time, for he ſays it was at Chriſtmaſs, but Mr. Smith ſays it was ſome time before.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Smith does not ſay ſo, the certain time he cannot tell exactly; but your Witneſſes ſay it was then.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p:
I do ſpeak as much as if I were upon my Oath; and I know what an Oath is, I thank God; and what it is to ſpeak before a Court of Judicature, and I know, and do ſpeak truth as much as if I were upon my Oath; and I do ſay I did not
hear Colledge, or any one elſe that was in that company at that time, ſpeak any thing reflecting upon the King and Government, or any thing tending towards it.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Can you remember a matter ſo diſtinctly, which Dr. Oates ſays was a year and half ago?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: No, this Summer was twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: And can you tell ſo long ago, not only your own actions, but teſtify to all other mens actions too that were in the room?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: I cannot tell what Dr. Oates's memory is as to the time, but I remember the place, the occaſion, and the perſons that were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: And you take upon you to have ſuch a perfect memory, as to the actions of all the perſons that were in the room.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: I do not ſpeak of all that was done; but I ſay I remember no ſuch thing that was ſaid, and I believe no ſuch thing was ſaid, and have given you my reaſons why. But, my Lord, that which I ſay further for Mr. Colledge, is this; I do hear ſomething pretended, as if he provided Arms to go for Oxford. I have known him this three years, or thereabouts; and, my Lord, I do know that he did uſually ride with a caſe of Piſtols before him. And before that time I had occaſion to borrow his Horſe of him, at the Election for Weſtminſter the laſt Parliament that ſat there, and I had it then with a caſe of Piſtols. I likewiſe borrowed it at Michaelmas laſt, the ſame Horſe, and the ſame Piſtols they were: I did at the ſame time ſee a Suit of Silk-Armour, which he told me he did provide againſt the Papiſts, for he ſaid he did expect we should have a brush with them. Said I, do not trouble your ſelf for that, they dare not meddle; ſaid he, this will do no harm. And, as I remember, it was a Suit of Armour made of Silk, to wear under a Coat.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: It was Silk Armour only for the thruſt of a Sword. And I aſſure you, my Lord, I had but one Suit, but one caſe of Piſtols, and but one Horſe, I had two before, but they did not then make a Traytor of me, that was all that ever I had; but if I had ten Horſes, and never ſo many Armours, I declare it upon my Salvation, I intended it for nothing but againſt the Papiſts, if they ſhould make a diſturbance, and whatever I did was with that deſign, and truly, by the Grace of God, I would not have been the laſt man then; but I ſee, whatever I provided my ſelf with for that, they have turned it all another way, that it might be believed the Proteſtants were againſt the King and the eſtablished Government.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Thoſe obſervations may be proper for you at laſt: Go on now with your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, I am not a man of that great memory, I may forget it, and therefore I ſpeak it now whilſt I think of it.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Set it down in your paper.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Smith ſays I talked with him coming from Richard's Coffee-Houſe till we came to the Tavern; I do declare it, I went away before him, and went away with Dr. Oates.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Ask Mr. Smith that queſtion, if you will.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray Sir, do you know who went together thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: I dare not undertake to ſay that, I cannot tell whether he went from the Rainbow-Coffee-Houſe with us, or no.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He ſays after we had dined we divided our ſelves into Cabals, two and two together: I do declare it, as that which is the real truth, I fell aſleep behind the Table, if any body was divided, it is more than I know; but Mr. Smith, you can tell, becauſe he ſays I ſpoke Treaſon to him when I was in the room, he and I in one Cabal.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. S.
sp.p: My Lord, I remember nothing of that, nor do believe it, for I told you the room was ſo little that we could not divide our ſelves; and it is impoſſible in ſuch a little compaſs where we were, ſo many as we were, 14 or 15 of us; it may be one might talk to another that was next to him, but then the company muſt hear, and whether they did ſo or no, I cannot tell, I do not remember Mr. Smith's ſaying any thing to any particular perſon, but the great engagement was between Dr. Oates and Mr. Savage, and about ſome queſtions in Divinity, and that is the great matter I took notice of.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: However, my Lord, I declare it, that was above a twelve-month ago, and I hope your Lordship and the Jury does obſerve that there was no new Arms were found but what were provided a great while ago: All that know me, know I was never without a caſe of Piſtols and an Horſe, though I was but a Joyner, and there is no more that you ſee now. And as to what Smith ſaid about our going into Cabals, that you hear Mr. Smith denies.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Will you call any other Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Yes, if it pleaſe your Lordship, Do you know no more, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Smith.
sp.p: I know no other thing, if I did, I would declare it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Call Dr. Oates's Brother, Mr. Samuel Oates. My Lord, thus you ſee Smith's teſtimony is falſe.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: I do not ſee this contradicts his Oath, for he ſpeaks of ſeveral times that he did ſpeak with you, one was at Wilcox's, which is this they ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Smith ſays there was only that great diſcourſe going on in the room, and there was no ſuch things as Cabals which he ſpeaks of.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What do you ſay as to this Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Do you know Narrative Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: What do you know of him? Were you at the Dinner which Mr. Wilcox gave your Brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I was at that Dinner.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Were you at the Coffee-Houſe when I went along with your Brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, we went with you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did Mr. Smith go with us?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Smith followed us.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you hear any Treaſonable diſcourſe between us?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Not the leaſt of a little word.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did we go into Cabals two and two together there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p:
There was nothing at all of cabals that I ſaw, from the time of going
to Dinner; for we came juſt as Dinner was going into the room, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: What do you mean by cabals?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: That is, as I diſcern by Mr. Colledge, as if there had been cabals amongſt the company.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: That is, going by couples.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What did they talk of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: There was nothing at all ſpoken of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What, did they ſay nothing all the while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Nothing but matter of common diſcourſe, matters of eating and drinking, and talking of Countrey affairs, there were ſeveral that had Lands in the Countrey, and they were talking of thoſe things.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Were you there all the while?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Heark you, Sir, were there no diſputations in Divinity?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Nor of Philoſophy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Why, pray Sir, did not Dr. Oates and Mr. Savage talk very pleaſantly of two great queſtions in Divinity, the Being of God, and the Immortality of the Soul?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: There was not a word of that, but only of common diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Are you ſure there was no ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Not that I know of in the leaſt. I ſat at Table with them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Was it ſuch a little room that you could hear all was ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: There was room enough.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: People cannot give a perfect account of all things that have paſſed ſo long ago.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I did not hear that diſcourſe my ſelf, becauſe I was aſleep behind the Table; and perhaps Mr. Oates cannot remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it before Dinner, or after Dinner, that Colledge fell aſleep behind the Table?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: He was not aſleep, to my remembrance, all the while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Recollect your ſelf, pray; was Mr. Colledge aſleep there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not remember he was.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible to give an account, and therefore Witneſſes in Negatives are of little value.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did Mr. Smith and you and I go together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Smith followed us.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: For you and I, and my Brother went together: You were a ſaying when we came out of the Coffee-Houſe in a jocoſe way, come Dr. I will go along with you, and be one of your Guard. You ſpoke it in a jeſting way; ſo you may, if you pleaſe, ſaid my Brother. And ſo he went by my Brother's ſide, and I went by Mr. Colledge's ſide.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Do you remember how long ago that was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: It was the laſt Summer, but to ſay exactly what month, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Oates, anſwer me this queſtion, pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Gen.
sp.p: From what place did you go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: From Richards Coffee-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Gen.
sp.p: Who went along with Colledge?

sp.speaker: M. Oates.
sp.p: He came along with my Brother and me; for he ſaid to my Brother, I will be one of your Guard.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Gen.
sp.p: Who went along with Mr. Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: I don't know, I took very little notice of things.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: 'Tis ſufficient that he can tell who went with Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: I remember one thing: Mr. Smith would fain have perſwaded me into ſomething that my Brother should talk, but I heard nothing; ſaid I, do not examine me upon ſuch things, for I took little notice of any thing; but this I can ſay, whereas he does charge Mr. Wilcox, the Gentleman did not ſpeak five words all the time he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: He does not uſe to be ſo melancholy, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: I did wonder at it my ſelf, but he was not long with us, for I do not think he was there a quarter of the time; it ſeems he had a Son ſick in the Countrey, and he was going thither.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Have you any thing againſt Macnamarra?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He is no Witneſs here.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Do you know any thing againſt Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Oates.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Then I can ſay no more to you.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Call Mr. Bolron.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Do you know John Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What ſay you againſt him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordship, the laſt 25th. of July Mr. Smith, and Mr. Mowbray, and my ſelf were travelling from York towards London. We lay the 24th. at and the 25th. we were travelling towards London: Mr. Smith did ask me, if I did remember what Diſcourſe there was betwixt Sir John Brooks and I at Ferry-bridge, when we were coming up before to London? I deſired him to tell me what diſcourſe, and I would tell him if I did remember it or no. So my Lord, he did ſay, the Diſcourſe was, that Sir John Brooks did ſay, there would be cutting of throats at Oxford, and that the Parliament did go provided, ſome with 8, ſome with 6, ſome with 4 men, and they were to meet at Grantham, and go together. This diſcourſe I did remember, that Sir John Brooks ſaid, they went with Horſe and Arms to ſecure them from High-way-men; and Sir John Brooks did then further declare, that the Diſcourſe was, there would be cutting of throats at Oxford, which made them go with Arms to defend themſelves. Mr. Smith did further upon the 25, 26, 27, and 28th. of July (and it was our frequent diſcourſe) tell me, that he had given His Majeſty an account of it, which occaſioned the Diſſolving of the Parliament: That Diſcourſe that was made to the King, was, that Sir John Brooks should ſay, there would be cutting
of throats at Oxford, and that the Parliament-men went provided with 4 or 5, 6 or 10 men apiece; and he did tell me, he had given a further account, that there was a Conſult a •
Grantham, wherein it was reſolved, that it was better to ſeize the King, than to let him go on. Now, this I knew nothing of, but he would have perſwaded me to have given in this Evidence againſt Sir John Brooks, as to this Diſcourſe. But I declare, I did never hear it, and Mr. Smith was the firſt man that ever I heard it from, I never heard it before in my life.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Would he have had you been an Evidence, and ſwore it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes; he ſaid he had given an account of it to the King, and if I did manage it rightly againſt my Lord Shaftsbury and Colledge, he would make me for ever; thoſe two perſons were mentioned all along. But I do declare it, I did never hear them ſpeak Treaſon againſt the King in my life. And he did further tell me, that I muſt ſay ſo and ſo; for if we did not agree, it would ſignifie nothing. But, my Lord, I know nothing of the matter, I never heard any one ſpeak of it but Mr. Smith. My Lord, this is true, Mr. Mowbray was the man that was by when it was diſcourſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: He would have had you ſworn it, would he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I diſcovered it to my Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you diſcover it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Soon after he came to Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Some time laſt week.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was it on Saturday laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was the beginning of the week.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: Thou art ſuch a Diſcoverer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, 'tis very true what I ſay. If I had known any ſuch thing, I would have diſcovered it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Thou wouldeſt have diſcovered it before that time, of my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, he hath been an Evidence againſt the Papiſts as well as Mr. Smith, and therefore pray Sir George don't make your flouriſhes upon him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeffer.
sp.p: He was an Evidence, but he had the misfortune never to be believed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of any Pictures of Mr. Colledges making? Have you ſeen Raree Shew?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Never in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you not ſhew it in Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, never in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Did you never declare to any Gentleman of Oxford, that Colledge made this Picture?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I have ſeen the Character of a Popish Succeſſor, but I never ſaw Raree Shew.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Hollow.
sp.p: Here is the very Gentleman, my Lord, that will make Oath of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He was ſuppoſed to make them, I did not know that he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p:
I do only deſire one thing, I do not say, that you ever had Raree
Shew, but did you ever tell any body that Colledge made any of theſe Pictures?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I have heard of ſuch a paper, but I did never ſee it in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Do you know that Gentleman, Mr. Bolron?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I know him not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: I would ask you, whether you ever had any diſcourſe with that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Never in my life.

div.stage: Then the Gentleman was ſworn, being a Maſter of Arts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: What is the Gentlemans Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Holloway.
sp.p: Mr. Charlett of Trinity Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: Pray Sir, do you know that perſon there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Charlett.
sp.p: My Lord, in the new Coffee-Houſe that was by the Schools, that was ſet up in the Parliament-time, there was a Gentleman that is in the Court (I think) one Mr. Daſhwood, and one Mr. Box were there together to drink a dish of Coffee, and and hearing that ſome of the Evidence were there, we deſired their company up, and that Gentleman was one; and among other Diſcourſe, they were ſpeaking of ſome Pictures, and they shewed us the Picture of the Tantivies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Did this man shew it you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Char.
sp.p: This very man; it was the Pictures of the Tantivies and the Towzer, and he told me they were made by Colledge, he was a very ingenious man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I know nothing of it, the Character of a Popish Succeſſor I have ſeen, but never the other, I never shewed him any ſuch thing.

div.stage: Then the Pictures were ſhewen him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Charlett.
sp.p: It was ſomething like this, but I cannot ſay for any of the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: The charcter of a Popish Succeſſor, I ſay I have ſeen, and Colledge himſelf hath told me he made the character of a Popish Succeſſor, I do not deny that I have ſeen that.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Would you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, I have ſomething more to ſay concerning Mr. Brian Hains; in January, February and April laſt, ſeveral times I was in his company, and I heard him ſay, he knew nothing of a Popish Plot, nor of a Presbyterian Plot neither, but if he were to be an Evidence he did not care what he ſwore, but would ſwear and ſay any thing to get money.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Did he tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear him ſay, to day he would be a Papiſt, to morrow a a Presbyterian, he did not care for Religion, he would never die for Religion, he would be of that Religion that had the ſtrongeſt party. My Lord, he told me ſo at my own Houſe in Fleet-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: He would ſay any thing for money, pray my Lord take notice of that, for ſo I find he does.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Then there is Dennis Macnamarra, and John Macnamarra.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: We have nothing to ſay to them.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p:
They have been Evidences againſt me, though you do not now produce them,
they are all in a ſtring, but they are not now brought becauſe my Witneſſes are prepared to anſwer them.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Will you call your next Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Mowbray, pray, Sir, do you know Narrative Smith, as he calls himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What do you know of it?

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: I came up from York with him when I returned, after I was commanded down upon the Kings account to give in Evidence againſt Sir Miles Stapleton, he came to me the third of Auguſt, and called at my Houſe in Yorkshire, and was very importunate for me to come up to London with him, for he ſaid, he had a Letter come to him which commanded his preſence at London very ſuddenly, and he produced that Letter which he ſaid came from a Gentleman of the Court, or ſome Court dependent; ſo he read the Letter in Mr. Bolrons hearing. We ſet forward on Sunday, and upon our journey to London he told me he had ſomething of importance to impart to me, ſo upon the Road he began to diſcourſe of the Parliament, and of the illegal proceedings and Arbitrary Power of the Two laſt Parliaments, he ſaid their proceedings were very illegal and arbitrary, and he began to open ſome of the Votes, as that which they voted, that thoſe that should lend the King money upon the Crown Lands, should be enemies to the King and Kingdom, and thoſe that counſelled the King to diſſolve the Parliament; and he repeated many Votes; and, ſaid he, theſe are ſigns of Arbitrary Power, and certainly they deſign to take off the King; ſo he proceeded further, to ask me what was the Diſcourſe of Sir John Brooks when we came up before, and he did much importune me to ſay, that Sir John Brooks did affirm there would be cutting of throats at Oxford, and that the King was to be ſeized there. I told him, I could have no plauſible pretence, becauſe I had no acquaintance with Sir John Brooks, nor did I come up with him; upon which he applied himſelf to Mr. Bolron, and importuned him for the ſame, he asked me who I came up with, I told him, I came up with Three members of Parliament, my Lord Fairfax, Sir John Hewly and Mr. Stern; he asked what Diſcourſe we had upon the Road? And he asked, whether they had any Diſcourſe that tended to juſtifie their former Votes? For he ſaid, if they did think to juſtifie any thing of thoſe Votes, or if they would not allow the King money, and ſtood upon the Bill of Excluſion, he ſaid, that was pretence enough for any man to ſwear that there was a Deſign againſt the King, and that the King was to be ſeized at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: An excellent pretence indeed, and like the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: He would have tempted me to ſwear againſt my Lord Shaftsbury the ſame. And he ſaid, it would be well if I did appear on Colledges Tryal at Oxon. for it was a thing of great conſequence; the Popish Plot was thrown out of doors, and no man was looked upon that did ſpeak of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Was all this in the preſence of Mr. Bolron?

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, when he was diſcourſing about Sir John Brooks, Mr. Bolron
rid up to us, and he applied himſelf to him, becauſe I told him I had no plaufible pretence to ſwear againſt him, having no acquaintance with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me ask you one queſtion; when came you from York?

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: We ſet forward the third day of Auguſt from Wentbridge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Pray who came with you in the company?

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Mr. Bolron.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: That was a Sunday, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Then pray, how long did you continue before you came to London?

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: I think we came in on the Thurſday after.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: When was the firſt time Mr. Smith came into your company?

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: Upon the road on Sunday.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Was that the firſt time?

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, He had been at York, and went further, and afterwards came to us.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: When did you come from York.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: About the Thurſday before, if I be not miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Was it in a week before.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes, within a week it was.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And you and Mr. Bolron came together.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And you left Mr. Smith behind.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And he overtook you upon the road.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes: He was to go further into the North as ſoon as the Tryal of Sir Miles Stapleton was over; and therefore he did very much importune me to ſtay in the Countrey till he came to go up with me.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: What day was the Tryal of Sir Miles Stapleton.

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: On the Monday before.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: You are ſure of that, and that Mr. Smith went further into the North.

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: I ſee him take Horſe.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: But he did not come into the company of you and Bolron till the Sunday after that.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: See ye, Sir, He did deſire me to ſtay in the Countrey till he came, for he had a buſineſs of great concernment to impart to me, but it would be a week or a fortnight ere he came, but yet he came in a shorter time; for he ſaid he had received a Letter that brought him up.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: You are ſure of this.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And you did not ſee him from the Monday before, till that Sunday.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Now then, I ask you where was that place that he met with you.

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: At Wentbridge.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And then you came from thence towards London the next day.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Now would I deſire to know of you, for I perceive he did attack you to ſay ſomething againſt Sir John Brooks, and finding that you could not do it, becauſe you had no acquaintance, he applied himſelf to Bolron. I would know, was it between that place and London.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: And after the third of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Yes, it was after we ſet out.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p:
I thought it had been the 24th. of July that you ſet out, and continued
your journey the 25, 26, 27, 28, and 29th. Alas, we have loſt a great deal of time between Bolron and Mowbray. Bolron ſaid it was the 25th. they lay at ſuch a place, and you are gotten to the third of Auguſt; you are miſtaken certainly, as to point of time.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: See, Sir, I will look in my Almanack, 'tis all ſet down there.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Let us ſee now if your Oxford journey be as well ſet down, as your journey to London is.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: Here is my Almanack, Sir. Mr. Jones. Here, look upon his Almanack.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Mr. Jones, I don't care for his Almanack, I had rather Mowbray and Bolron could bring their Almanacks together, and I would have them compared, to ſee whether the third of Auguſt in one, be the 25th. of July in the other. Did you diſcourſe with him upon the road the third of Auguſt, and not before; and Bolron that came up with you, diſcourſe with him the 25th. of July.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: I am miſtaken, I find.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Ay, that you are, one of you moſt groſly.

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: See, Sir, here is my Almanack, whereby. I find that it is my miſtake; but pray ſee, Sir, here it is ſet down; the day we came out was the 24th. the day we came to London was the 27th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: How didſt thou ſet out the third of Auguſt from that place, and yet come to London the 27th. of July.

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: I will refer my ſelf to Mr. Smith, as to the time we came up, and here is my Almanack.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: I will believe thy Almanack to ſpeak truth, though it have never ſo many errors about the changes of the weather, ſooner than I will believe thee.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I perceive the man is miſtaken in the month and the time; but pray, my Lord, will you pleaſe to ſee, for Juſtice ſake, if the Almanack be new writ.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: Look you, here is the matter, Mr. Colledge, he was asked again and again, what day it was, and he was poſitive to the third of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He was miſtaken, but his Almanack is right.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He ſpeaks rashly, that is the beſt can be ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: It was a miſtake of mine, Sir George, but my Almanack is right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Mowbray, don't enter into dialogues with me, I only make a little obſervation upon your Almanack.

sp.speaker: Mowbray.
sp.p: It was only my miſtake.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: You are a rash man to affirm ſo: if you had an Almanack, you should have conſulted it, or referred to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Nay, we have loſt a day even by your Almanack; for yours ſays it was the 27th. you came to Town, Bolron the 28th.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: I refer my ſelf to Mr. Smith, he can't deny but he came up with us at that time.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: You were examined at Sir Miles Stapleton's Tryal, was you not, Mowbray?

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.p: I was an Evidence there.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Did the Jury believe you?

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: They did acquit Sir Miles Stapleton.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: That is nothing to the purpoſe; ſo was Mr. Smith too.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Would you ask any thing further?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Mary Bolron.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: If you have any more Witneſſes, pray call them.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Mowbray, was Bolron's Wife by when this diſcourſe was?

sp.speaker: Mowbr.
sp.p: No, she was in Town, she did not go down with him at all.

sp.speaker: Lo. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Are you Bolron's Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask her?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Mrs. Bolron, Pray do you know Mr. John Smith?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, I do know him.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: What can you ſay of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bolron.
sp.p: He ſent ſeveral times for my Husband and Mowbray to my Houſe, ſomething he would have them be concerned in, ſome buſineſs he had in hand.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bolron.
sp.p: Within this three weeks, ſince he came up from York Aſſizes.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: You may ſee there was an underſtanding between them then.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Did they go accordingly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bol.
sp.p: Now and then they have gone to him, but they knew his buſineſs, becauſe they had diſcourſe with him, as they ſaid, upon the road, and they would not go.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Would you ask her any thing elſe; what do you know more?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bolron.
sp.p: Nothing, for I am not one that ſtirs much abroad.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Call Mr. Everard.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: As for Mr. Everard, I need not ask him whether he knows him, for they know one another well enough: But Mr. Everard, that I would ask you is this; what do you know of Mr. Smith, and of this contrivance againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: Mr. Smith I have been to ſee of late, and he told me he knew of no Presbyterian or Proteſtant Plot; and when my Lord Howard was tried, that is, the Bill brought againſt him, he ſaid he wondred how my Lord Howard could be Guilty, and that both himſelf and I were joyned as Evidence to that Jury, only to put a gloſs upon the Evidence; for, ſays he, I have nothing material to ſay.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Everard. Do you know any thing more concerning him, what he hath ſaid at other times concerning me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: I have told you already what I have heard him ſay, that he thought there was no Proteſtant or Presbyterian Plot, & that now of late within this little while.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray Sir, was there not ſome diſcourſe betwixt Juſtice Warcupp and you in Lincolns-Inn Walks?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: Is Juſtice Warcupp an Evidence here?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: 'Tis all but Evidence of a Presbyterian Plot; therefore, pray Sir, what was the diſcourſe between Juſtice Warcupp and you, what would he have had you done?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: I think it is not material, there is nothing of Mr. Warcupp in this Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: If the Court does allow of it, I will freely tell it.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
My Lord, the Papiſts deſign is to make a Proteſtant Plot to turn off their own, and
they begin with me, but if I should go, they would not be ſatisfied with me, they would be at others.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: There is nothing concerning a Presbyterian or Proteſtant Plot in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, if there be no Presbyterian Proteſtant Plot, and others to joyn in it, how could I do it by my ſelf; 'tis imposſible I should have ſuch a deſign of ſeizing the King, and improbable I should ſpeak it. Now, my Lord, this man was ſollicited to come in for an Evidence of ſuch a Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: I tell you it is not material, Juſtice Warcupp is not concerned in your Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: Juſtice Warcupp would have perſwaded me to have ſworn againſt ſome Lords a Presbyterian Plot, but I deny that I know any ſuch thing of them.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: The Papiſts aim is not at me only, but at others.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
L. c. j.
sp.p: Would he have perſwaded you to ſay any thing that was not true?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: He did not ſay poſitively thoſe words, but this he ſaid, I knew ſeveveral Lords—

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Now here is Mr. Juſtice Warcupp's ſame traduc'd behind his back in the face of the Countrey, and it is nothing to this cauſe before us.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know what he knows of theſe things, and that he may ſpeak it out, 'tis a material thing for me and others: Here is a deſign of the Papiſts to turn a Plot upon the Proteſtants, they begin with me, and if they have my blood, who may feel the effect of it next I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Truly I think it not material to your caſe, and indeed 'tis of ill conſequence to have any man traduced behind his back, as Juſtice VVarcupp is.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, Macnamarra told me, that that man would have ſeduced him to have retracted his Evidence; upon my Salvation 'tis true.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: We meddle not with Macnamarra neither, he is no Evidence againſt you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Macnamarra hath ſworn againſt me at the Old-Baily, and at the finding of this Bill, but they have laid him by upon ſome trick or other: I deſire Mr. Everard may tell what he knows.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: I would not reflect upon any perſon, nor will I anſwer it, if the Court do not think fit.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, this is foul play, if I die my ſelf for my Countrey ſake, I can do it freely, and the will of God be done; I would have the truth out for the ſake of the Proteſtants.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: I am very willing to tell the truth, if the Court think fit.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: I ſee not that he ſays Mr. VVarcupp would have had him ſwear that which was not true.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ever.
sp.p:
But this he ſaid, if the Court will allow me to ſpeak it; Juſtice VVarcupp ſaid, that certainly there was a Presbyterian Plot, and ſuch things; and that ſome Lords, ſome of the Proteſtant proteſting Lords muſt be guilty of it, and ſaid he, certainly you
know much of it, You know ſuch and ſuch things, therefore you may ſafely ſwear it, if I knew it; ſo by argument he would firſt prove there was a Plot and combination amongſt thoſe Lords, and then ſaid he this you may ſafely ſwear.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: What is this to your purpoſe, Mr. Colledge, only Mr. Warcup's name is brought upon the ſtage when he is not here to vindicate himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Would you ask him any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: If he does know any thing more of any of them, I deſire he would ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ev.
sp.p: Concerning Mr. Haynes, he told me it was neceſſity that drove him to ſpeak any thing againſt the Proteſtants, and the hard Pay and the Gratitude he did receive from the Citizens.

div.stage: Then Mr. Jones acquainted the Court that Mr. Warcup was juſt come in, and deſired to vindicate himſelf. But the Kings other Counſel waved it, ſaying there was no weight in it.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Where did he tell you this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ev.
sp.p: In the fields near Grays-Inn.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: How long ſince?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ev.
sp.p: About three weeks ago. I asked him, Mr. Haynes, ſaid I, I would not draw you from your Teſtimony in any thing; but how can this be congruous to what you have ſaid formerly, That you knew nothing by them? The truth is, ſaid he, I will not ſay much to excuſe my ſelf, but my Wife was reduced to that neceſſity, that she begg'd at Rouſe's door, and craved ſome Salary, and Mr. Rouſe would not give her any; and, ſaid he, meer neceſſity drove me to it.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: He found better pay in another place.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ev.
sp.p: And, ſays he, 'tis Self-preſervation in the next place: for I was brought in guilty when I was taken up, and therefore I was obliged to do ſome things to ſave my Life.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, and Gentlemen, obſerve what this Gentleman ſays, Haynes takes this courſe to deſtroy innocent perſons for his own preſervation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ever.
sp.p: Beſides, he told me, there is a Judgment impending upon the Nation, ſaid he, either upon the King, or upon the people, I know not which; but theſe Iriſh mens ſwearing againſt them, is juſtly fallen upon them for their Injuſtice againſt the Iriſh in outing them of their Eſtates.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: So he did it then by way of revenge. For his Country-men, I have nothing of their Eſtates, I am ſure; therefore they had no cauſe to ſwear againſt me. But, Mr. Everard, have you any more to ſay concerning any of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: No more concerning thoſe perſons that have ſworn againſt you, I can ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: As to Dugdale or Turbervile?

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: As to this Presbyterian Plot, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ever.
sp.p: If the Court does allow concerning other perſons; but I would not intrude any thing but what the Court shall think fit.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p:
I know not but they may come in againſt me; therefore pray tell what
you know. Mr. Everard, do you know any thing more? Pray let me know what you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: Nothing of any perſon that hath appeared againſt you as yet, but what I have told you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: They may do, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. c. juſt.
sp.p: And then we may properly hear him to them, and not before.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I deſire to know who they are; pray let me know their Names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Everard.
sp.p: Fitzgerald.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He hath been no Witneſs here.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Call Thomas Parkhurſt.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What do you ask him now he is here?

sp.speaker: College.
sp.p: What do you know concerning Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Parkhurſt.
sp.p: Sir, the latter end of the laſt November, when the Parliament ſat at Weſtminſter, ſeveral times Mr. Dugdale having promiſed me his further Narrative to publish, which he printed, I met him ſeveral times; one time I met him at Richard's Coffee-Houſe, and it was towards the evening before we went away; he told me and Mr. Symonds, that he was to ſpeak with Dr. Tongue; and he told us, that this Dr. Tongue did lie at Mr. Colledge's; and he having ſpoken the day before, and ſeveral times, of the danger he was in of his being aſſaſſinated by the Papiſts, M. Symonds and I offered to go with him, we took a coach; for we did not know where Mr. Colledge lived: he had then a Rheum in his Eyes, and was not well; ſo we accompanied him to Mr. Colledge's to speak with Dr. Tongue. It was evening when we went; and whilſt we took a pipe of Tobacco, in our diſcourſe we were ſpeaking of the times, and of the danger of the Papiſts; ſo Colledge took down a ſteel Hat that hung up there, which he ſaid he had, and he ſaid he had a quilted Coat of defenſive Armour, and he ſaid he had a Blunderbuſs in his Houſe, and two Piſtols. But I little thought of any thing of this, neither did I know well what I was ſubpoena'd down for: But theſe Arms I ſaw in his Houſe, and it was only in diſcourſe that he was provided againſt the Papiſts; ſo I put the ſteel Hat upon my Head and pulled it off again, and ſo did Mr. Symonds.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Did I ſay any thing, Sir, who I had thoſe Arms againſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Parkhurſt.
sp.p: At that time there was no diſcourſe in the world, but of the danger from the Papiſts; and he ſaid he was provided for them, if they did come to make any diſturbance.

sp.speaker: L. ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When was it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Parkhurſt.
sp.p: It was about the latter end of November. I have the Narrative that I printed, which was the 23th or 24th; and I have no directions but that to remember the time. So we carried Mr. Dugdale. home again in a Coach and gave him a pint of Wine at his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: This does not contradict Mr. Dugdale at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Parkhurſt.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale does own this for a truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: So may any body own it.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Where is Mr. Symonds? Pray, Sir, what do you know of Mr. Dugdale? Mr. Symonds. What about, Sir?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I have your Name here, Sir, but I know not for what.

sp.speaker: Mr. Symonds.
sp.p: I can ſay the ſame that Mr. Parkhurſt did; that I ſuppoſe is the buſiſineſs. All I know of it is this: I was with Mr. Parkhurſt and Mr. Dugdale at Richards Coffee-Houſe ſome time in November, I think it was about the printing of Mr. Dugdales further Information; and Mr. Dugdale was ſaying Dr. Tongue had ſent for him, but ſpoke as if he was fearful of ſome danger in going alone; ſo we proffered to go along with him, and we took a coach at the Coffee-Houſe-door, and went with him to Dr. Tongue, who lodged at Mr. Colledges. When we came into the Room, Mr. Parkhurſt and I thought fit we should in civility withdraw, which we did; and Mr. Colledge brought us down into another Room, where we ſat and took a pipe of Tobacco, and talking about the common diſcourſe of the times, about the Papiſts and the danger from them, there hung up in Mr. Colledges Room ſome Arms; what they were, I dare not charge my memory with to ſwear particularly, but I do think there was a Silk coat of mail, and there was a cap of ſteel, and, as I take it, it was covered with cloth or ſome ſuch thing; what elſe I can't well ſay: I think there was a Blunderbuſs and a caſe of Piſtols: And all the diſcourſe that I remember then, was only this; Speaking of the Papiſts, and ſome fears as if there would be an Inſurrection amongſt them, ſaid he, Let the Papiſt Rogues begin when they will, I am ready to defend my ſelf for one. This is all I know.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how long ago was this? Dr. Tongue died before Chriſtmas at my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Symonds.
sp.p: I cannot tell exactly when it was; but during the Seſſion of Parliament I am ſure it was, and as I take it, in November the latter end.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: So then, pray, my Lord, ſee that theſe Arms they charge me withal, were provided before Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: But there is nothing that contradicts Dugdale's Teſtimony in this.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: It does ſufficiently contradict him.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: I do not ſee that this does at all contradict what he hath ſaid; but do you obſerve what you will upon it, when you come to make your Defence.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: A Gentleman below deſires you to call Mr. Yates.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what do you know concerning Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Yates.
sp.p:
I know that Mr. Dugdale ſent for me to a Coffee-Houſe to beſpeak a Piſtol for you, and told me that when I had made the Piſtol, I should deliver it to Mr. Colledge. and Mr. Dugdale promiſed to pay for it when I had done it. Now ſome time after I did ſome ſmall matter for Mr. Dugdale, cleaned his Piſtols, or ſome ſmall buſineſs; and Mr. Dugdale asked me if I would drink a pint of Wine, which I agreed to; and being at the Tavern, Mr. Dugdale asked me if Mr. Colledges Piſtol were done. I told him no, it was not as yet. So I asked Mr. Dugdale, becauſe he had promiſed to give Mr. Colledge a Piſtol, what obligation there was betwixt Mr. Colledge and him, that he should give him a Piſtol? to which he anſwered, that Mr. Colledge had been ſerviceable to him in lending him a pair of Piſtols to ride withal ſometimes. So he gave him a Piſtol to ſatisfie him for the wearing of his Piſtols now and then. I thought, ſaid I, Mr. Colledge did impoſe upon your good nature too much, not but that I believe Mr. Colledge
is a very honeſt man, and ſtands up for the good of the King and the Government. Yes, ſaid Mr. Dugdale, I believe he does, and I know nothing to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Yates.
sp.p: A little after the Parliament ſat at Oxford; for I never knew Mr. Colledge before Mr. Dugdale ſet me a work for him.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Yates, pray was there nothing in the Coffee-Houſe about one that he asked to go with him, when he ſaid he knew nothing againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Yates.
sp.p: I heard one ſay—

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: You muſt ſpeak your own knowledge, you muſt not tell a tale of a Tub of what you heard one ſay.

sp.speaker: Yates.
sp.p: I heard it affirmed—

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser jeff.
sp.p: But by whom?

sp.speaker: Yates.
sp.p: By a perſon in the Coffee-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Who was that perſon?

sp.speaker: Yates.
sp.p: By one of the Servants of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: That is no Evidence at all: if you know any thing of your own knowledge, ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Is he here?

sp.speaker: Yates.
sp.p: No, I think not.

sp.speaker: Mr. ju. jones.
sp.p: How long do you think we muſt ſit here to hear other peoples ſtories.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: If you know any thing of your own knowledge, I ſay, ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray let me ask you that queſtion again: When was this that he ſaid he believed he was an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Yates.
sp.p: It was about three weeks after the Parliament ſat at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Then he does me wrong now; for if I were an honeſt man then, it cannot be true that he ſays of me.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Who do you call next?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, who hath been ſworn againſt me?

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: There is Stephen Dugdale, John Smith, Bryan Haynes, Edward Turbervile, Sir William Jennings, and Mr. Maſters.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Call Mr. Clayton. My Lord, at his Houſe it was I lay in Oxford, and that Dugdale ſays I ſpake ſome of the Treaſonable words: Pray Sir, do you know what time I came to Oxford?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: I remember it very well, it was at the time the Parliament ſat at Oxford, about two or three days after it began.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray what Arms did I bring to your Houſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: As to the matter of Arms, ther was no other but a Sword and a pair of Piſtols; a pair of Piſtols in his Holſters, and his Sword by his ſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there no Silk Armor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: I ſaw none, if it pleaſe you; ſuch a thing might be.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, I continued at his Houſe from my coming in to my going out, and that was till after the Parliament was Diſſolved; and I came after they were ſat: But heark you, Mr. Clayton, Mr. Dugdale ſays he was with me at your Houſe: Did you ever ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: I remember I have ſeen Dugdale at my Houſe, but never in your company.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Did you ſell any mum?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayt.
sp.p: No, I never did ſell any in my life.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Becauſe he ſays we had mum there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: I never ſaw him there with you, nor changed any word with him, as I know of.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Was he never in the company of Colledge at your houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Clayton.
sp.p: Not that I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: You don't know all the companies that come into your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, I am told there are ſome that came from the Town where I was born that know me, and have known me this 24 or 25 years together, if you think that material for me to prove whether I am a Proteſtant or no.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: If you will make out that, you may. But 'tis your Loyalty that is in queſtion. If you will produce any that can make it appear, that you uſe to honour the King in your diſcourſe, or ſo, that is ſomething.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: If I am a Proteſtant, then the deſign is plain, theſe men ſwear to make a Proteſtant Plot, and turn the Plot off the Papiſts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: What Church do you frequent in London to hear Divine Service?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I have received the Sacrament ſeveral times, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: When were you laſt at the publick Church?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I hope I may be a Proteſtant if I have not gone thither; but however, I do uſe to go to Church.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Well, call whom you will.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Is Thomas Deacon there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: He lives, my Lord, in the Pariſh where I was born. If you pleaſe Mr. Deacon to give my Lord an account what you know of me from my childhood.

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: I have known Mr. Colledge ever ſince he was a youth, he was born in the Town where I live.

sp.speaker: L. ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: At Watford, a Town in Hertfordſhire. There he lived till he was a man, and married a Neighbours Daughter of mine, and lived there while he had two children; I never knew but that he was a very honeſt man, frequented and kept to the Church of England all along, and paid every man his own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long is it ago ſince he left that place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: I can't directly tell how long it is truely, but I think 'tis eighteen years ſince you left Watford.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: 'Tis fourteen years ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: You ſay fourteen, and they ſay eighteen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: I ſay, I cannot exactly tell.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: But Mr. Deacon, I have been in your Country lately.

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: He uſed to come there once or twice a year generally to ſee his friends I have heard him delare himſelf againſt the Popish Church always very much.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Did you never hear him talk againſt the Government?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: No, never in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Nor againſt the King:

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: Nor againſt the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Was he in your Country the laſt Eaſter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: I think it was about Eaſter he was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Was he at Church there then, and received the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Deacon.
sp.p: I know not whether he was there of the Lords-day or no: He did quarter at another Town, at Buſhy, where he has a Brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Well, call another.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Whitaker.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: What is your Chriſtian Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: William.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: What do you ask of him?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Whether he knows me and my Education.

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: Sir, I have known him this ſix and twenty years. I knew his Parents, I know his mother, she lives now at Watford. I have known his behaviour to be very civil and good; a very good Church-man he was when he lived with us; and I have inquired, and find he has the ſame Reputation in the Parish where he laſt lived in Blackfryers: He was no Jeſuit nor Papiſt, I dare aver; he hath flouted them & mocked them with their Wooden Gods, and the like; for he never could endure that Perſwaſion.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: He is not queſtioned for that, but for Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you ever hear me ſpeak any thing againſt the Government?

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: I never knew of any ill behaviour of him in my life.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: But did you ever hear me ſay any thing againſt His Majeſty or the Government?

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: Never that I know of. I knew him a Souldier for His Majeſty, in which ſervice he got a fit of ſickneſs, which had like to have coſt him his life; he lay many months ill, to his great charge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. jeff.
sp.p: Where was it he was in His Majeſties Service?

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: At Chatham-buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: It was under my Lord Rocheſter. But, my Lord, I have a Teſtimonial under the Hands of ſeventy people of Watford, to give an account of my good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: He hath been gone thence theſe eighteen years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitaker.
sp.p: He hath come there almoſt every half year, ſometimes three or four times in a year, becauſe his mother lives there now, and he came to pay his reſpects to her. His Children lived and went to School with us.

sp.speaker: L. c. juſt.
sp.p: Come, who do you call elſe?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Mr. Neal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: I can ſay no more than the other men before me. I know the man, he was bred and born at Watford, he lived there ſeveral years, he married a Wife out of the Neighbourhood, frequented the publick Worship.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: How long ago is this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: Sixteen or ſeventeen years ago. But then he uſed to come once or twice a year into the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Did you ever hear me ſpeak any thing againſt the King or the Government.

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: No, never in my life.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: How long is it ago ſince you were in my company laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: When you were in Town laſt I never heard you ſay any thing that was ill.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: How long is it ago ſince we were at the White Hart together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: It was about Spring.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I ſaid right, my Lord, I was there about Eaſter. Pray did you ever hear me ſpeak for the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: Truly the diſcourſe we had I never uſed to keep in my mind, but I never heard him ſpeak any thing againſt the King or the Government.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Were you much converſant with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Neal.
sp.p: When he came down to give his mother a viſit, and ſee his Neighbours, we uſed always to ſee one another.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray will you call Mr. Tanner and Mr. Remington.

sp.speaker: Mr. Remington.
sp.p: I ſay I have known Stephen Colledge theſe forty years, and I have known that he was always an honeſt man. He was a Souldier ſome time, but he always went to Church, was no Conventi • ler; and uſed to viſit his Neighbours when he came down to ſee his mother, and was always looked upon to be a very good man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jeff.
sp.p: You ſay you knew him a Souldier, pray when was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Remington.
sp.p: About the time of Harwich buſineſs. That is all I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Come, what ſay you? what do you ask him Mr. Colledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tanner.
sp.p: I have known Stephen Colledge from a child forty years, he was born at Watford, his Father worked with my Father, and great intimate acquaintance we had with him, and ſaw him very often; I never knew any fault in him, and I never heard a bad report of him in all the Town of Watford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Have you ſeen him at Church lately?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tanner.
sp.p: No, I have not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I would fain know whether this man hath been at Church himſelf; he looks as if he had not.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I know not whether he hath been at the Church you mean or no; but he may be an honeſt man and a Proteſtant for all that.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Call another.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Peter Norreys.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: What do you ask him, Mr. Colledge? here he is.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Do you know any thing concerning Mr. Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Norreys.
sp.p: I was once in the Hercules Pillars, where was Sir William Waller, Macnamarra, Mr. Joy, and five or ſix of us together; and Mr. Smith was there, and we were talking concerning the Parliament approaching at Oxon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Tell the Names of the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Noreys.
sp.p: Sir William VValler, Macnamarra, Mr. Ivy, Mr. Lewes, Macnamarra's Brother, and I, and Mr. Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Well ſaid; we don't meddle with any of theſe, but Mr. Smith.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: Was John Smith there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Norreys.
sp.p: He was there.

sp.speaker: Lo. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, go on then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Norreys.
sp.p: We were talking of the Parliament at Oxon. Says Sir VVilliam VValler, moſt of the Parliament-men are afraid to go up to the Parliament. Truly, ſaid Smith, I hope they will be provided to go, if they do go. Says Sir VVilliam VValler, I shall be provided with the reſt of my friends; and Mr. Colledge ſaid, I will go up with the reſt of the Parliament-men; I shall be provided too, ſays moſt of the Evidence; ſays Sir VVilliam VValler, Will you go along with me, and I will provide you with an Horſe; ſaid he, I have an Horſe of my own, and if it pleaſe God I will have nothing elſe to do but to go along with the Parliament, and I will not neglect it. This was all the diſcourſe of the company for that night.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Did you hear Mr. Smith ſay any thing againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Norreys.
sp.p: No, not a word at all.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: But this were a material Evidence againſt others of the Confederates, if they had been examined.

sp.speaker: Mr. Norreys.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at the Amſterdam Coffee-Houſe the 23. of June laſt, and there was Mr. Denis Macnamarra; ſaid he, Will you go, and I will give you a pot of Ale.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: There is nothing of Denis Macnamarra in queſtion before us. If you have any thing to ſay againſt any of the Witneſſes that have been ſworn, go on with your Evidence, we muſt not hear ſtories of other people.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: He would ſpeak againſt ſome men that have ſworn againſt me, but are left out for ſome Reaſons I know not. Pray call Mr. Thomas Norreys.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, he knew me in this Country ſome fifteen or ſixteen years ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: My Lord, I have been acquainted with Mr. Colledge about ſixteen or eighteen years, and he hath always carried himſelf very civilly and well, and he kept to the Church for a conſiderable time as duely as any Parishoner did.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: How long have you known him?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: This ſixteen years.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: You live in this Country, don't you.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: Yes, at Aylworth.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I was at Aſtrop-wells laſt year. I believe Mr. Juſtice Levins ſaw me there.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: Yes, I was there with you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: VVe did diſcourſe commonly then concerning the Papiſts, Pray, Sir, did you find me inclined to the Popiſh intereſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: You ſpoke very much againſt them.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: Did you ever hear me ſpeak againſt the King or the Government?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: No, I never heard it; for if he were my Brother, I should have diſcovered it.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: How often have you ſeen him?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Norreys.
sp.p: Very often, and converſed much with him.

sp.speaker: Collede.
sp.p: My Lord, as to the papers charged upon me that they were mine, I declare I know not of them. Dugdale ſays I owned them, and the Letter and ſeveral Prints; but, my Lord, I had done my ſelf a great injury if I had done or owned thoſe things he hath charged me withal. I never could make a Picture, nor never did draw a Picture in my life; and that very perſon that he ſays I owned I got it to be Printed by, hath denied it before the King and Council; for he there teſtified that he did not know the perſon that cauſed it to be Printed.

sp.speaker: L. ch. juſt.
sp.p: How came you to have ſo many ſeized in your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, here is Elizabeth Hunt, the Maid by whom they were taken in, and who can give you an account of it. I cannot deny but that they were in my Houſe; but that I was the Author, or did take them in, is as great a miſtake as ever was made. Call Elizabeth Hunt. I do not know whether Curtis be in Town, but this I am confident, he was examined before the King and Council, and He and his VViſe denied it.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: He shall be called if he be here.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I know nothing of the Printing of them, nor was I the Author of them.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: They were diſperſed by you up and down.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: That they were in my Houſe, I believe, my Lord; and this woman will tell you how, my Lord. Pray tell the Court how theſe Papers that are called the Raree-Shew came to be in my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: A Porter brought three bundles to our Houſe, and asked whether my Maſter was not within: I told him no, he was not. Said he, theſe Papers are to be left here: ſaid I, who do they come from: ſaid he, 'tis all one for that, you muſt pay me, and I muſt leave them here; ſo I gave him ſix pence, and he left the Papers, but I never ſaw the man ſince, nor before. And, my Lord, I never read them what they were; but I ſaw they were ſuch ſort of Prints as thoſe.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: How long was it before they were ſeized?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: A matter of ſeven or eight weeks.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Lord, it ſeems they were put in a Box, and left in my Counting-Houſe: I never touched them, but there they ſtaid, for ought I know, till they were taken.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: You were Colledge's Servant, were you not?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, I neither knew the Printer nor the Author; but I heard a man was in trouble about them, upon a By-Law in the Stationers Company

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How came you by that Original?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Have you it there? I know of none was produced. But if I were a perſon concerned, it were no Treaſon; and, my Lord, I hope you will do me that Juſtice, to let the Jury know they are not Treaſon, none of theſe Papers. And I do declare I know nothing of the Original, the Printer, nor the Author.

sp.speaker: Lo. ch. juſt.
sp.p: You ſpend time in making obſervations out of order of time: When you have given your Evidence, then make your obſervations.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
L. c. j.
sp.p: No, it was eight weeks before you were taken they were left there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Did you tell you Maſter ſoon after they were left there?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. jeff.
sp.p: Within what time did you tell him?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: I believe it was a week or a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was your Maſter all that time?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: He was in the countrey.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: My Lord, I did ſee them there, I muſt confeſs, I do not deny but I ſaw them there, but I knew not whence they came, nor whoſe they were; nor did I ever intend to meddle with them, nor concern my ſelf about them. VVhat have you to ſay more?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: Concerning Mr. Dugdale, if I may ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: Ay, go on.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: I went to receive the money of Mr. Dugdale that he owed my Maſter, and asking him for it, he ſaid he would pay me ſuch a time to morrow morning, if I would come for it; but when I came, he had not the money ready for me. Sir, ſaid I, I think 'tis very hard that you should keep my Maſters money from him, and yet you go and ſwear againſt his life too: what do you think we shall do at home in the Family, if you keep my Maſters money, and he be in Priſon? Said he, there is a great deal of do about my ſwearing againſt your Maſter, more than needs; but as I hope for Salvation, I do not believe Mr. Colledge had any more hand in any conſpiracy againſt his Majeſty, than the child unborn. Here is Dugdale, let him deny it if he can.

sp.speaker: Dugdale.
sp.p: As I hope for Salvation I did not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: Upon my Salvation 'tis true what I ſay

sp.speaker: Stephens.
sp.p: This was the maid that hid her Maſters papers when they were ſearched for.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jeff.
sp.p: Be quiet; art thou entring into dialogues with the maid now.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Mr. Stevens, 'tis well known what a man you are to propagate Witneſſes. My Lord, she gave me an account of this in the Tower before I came away, that Dugdale deſired to ſpeak with Mr. Smith, and told her that nothing that he had to ſay would touch my life.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: As I am alive 'tis true.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Mr. Dugdale denies it now.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: He is not a right man if he denies it, for he told it me twice.

sp.speaker: Colledge.
sp.p: I told Mr. Smith of it, when he had leave to come to me: I told him what the maid ſaid he had ſaid to her, and this was three weeks ago; ſaid he, I will ſpeak with him with all my heart, if he has a mind to ſpeak with me; for he hath ſaid that he hath nothing againſt her Maſter that can touch an hair of his head, nor nothing that can touch his life; that he knew nothing of a Plot or contrivance againſt the King; and if I could help it, I had as lieve have given a hundred pound I had never ſpoken what I have. This he ſaid to her.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: You tell her what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: Sir, he does not tell me; for Mr. Dugdale ſaid thoſe very things to me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: This is an account I had when I was a Priſoner; I could not direct her.

sp.speaker: L. c. j.
sp.p: Do you deny what they ſay to be true, Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugd.
sp.p: My Lord, she came to me for money, I told her I had it not ready, but would pay her; and in the Shop, before the Apprentice boy, she deſired of me that I would write two or three words what I had to ſay againſt her Maſter, and I told Mr. Graham of it. So, ſaid I, I cannot tell, I have not the papers, nor what informations I have given againſt him. So she came again the next morning, and she was at me to write down what I ſaid. I wonder, ſaid I, your Maſter will ſend you! had not he as good ſend Mr. Smith, who is his counſel? And this was all the words we had.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: My Lord, I do ſolemnly aſſure you, he ſaid he would write down what he had ſaid againſt my Maſter, and would fain ſpeak with Mr. Smith; for there was more ado made about it than needs.

sp.speaker: Dugd.
sp.p: Mr. Graham can tell what it was; for I came and told him immediately.

sp.speaker: Lo. c. j.
sp.p: Did you tell her you had nothing to ſay againſt her Maſter that would touch his life?

sp.speaker: Dugdale.
sp.p: I could not ſay that I had ſaid nothing againſt her Maſter, for she asked me that I would write down what I had ſaid; but I told her I knew not what was Treaſon, that muſt be referred to the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. jones.
sp.p: Did he ſpeak it openly or privately to you?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: He did not ſpeak it aloud; no body heard him but my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dugd.
sp.p: It was in the Shop, and the Apprentice-boy was by.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. Levins.
sp.p: Was this after he had been at the Old-Baily, or before?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: Yes, it was after he had been at the Old-Baily, and after he had been at Oxon. too.

sp.speaker: Mr. juſt. Levins.
sp.p: Then it was before the Court, what could be made of it?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: She had gone forty times for the money I had lent him out of my pocket, and I lent him that when I had little more for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Hunt.
sp.p: I did tell him, Mr. Dugdale, if you can't let me have my Maſters money, if you pleaſe to tell me what you have made Oath againſt my Maſter.
